title: AI Nexus- Organizing AI for Innovation
description:
Guidelines:

Open to all students, professionals, and AI/ML enthusiasts.
Participants must be at least 16 years old.
Teams can consist of 2 to 4 members.
Inter-specialization teams are allowed (teams with diverse backgrounds in AI/ML-related fields).
There will be 2 problem statements related to AI/ML innovation.

Format:

Teams will solve 1 problem statement during the hackathon.
Code submissions and presentations will be required.
Participants will present their solutions at the end of the event.

Duration of the Event:

24 hours: The event will begin at the specified start time and end 24 hours later.
Time Zone: Make sure to mention the event’s time zone

Rules:

Originality: All code and solutions must be original. No plagiarized content will be allowed.
Code Submission: Participants must submit their code through the designated platform. Ensure the code is well-documented and executable.
Use of External Resources:
Use of third-party APIs and libraries is allowed, but proper attribution must be given.
Pre-trained models or datasets can be used, but they should be clearly mentioned in your solution.
Team Collaboration: Teams must collaborate remotely during the event. No external help (from non-team members) is allowed.
Presentation: Teams will have a maximum of 10 minutes to present their project, followed by 5 minutes for Q&A.
Judging Criteria: Innovation and creativity.
Functionality and technical execution.
Scalability and potential real-world impact.
Quality of code and presentation.
Code of Conduct: Participants must adhere to professional behavior. Any unethical behavior or violation of rules may result in disqualification.

title: SGU Hackathon-2025
description:
Hackathon Guidelines for Participants
PPT Guidelines


The hackathon theme will be provided by the organizers. Open innovation is not allowed.


A PPT template will be shared to maintain consistency in presentations. Participants must use this template.


The presentation should cover problem statement, proposed solution, technical approach, implementation details, and future scope.


PPT must be submitted before the deadline along with other required files. Late submissions will not be accepted.


Ensure the slides are clear, visually appealing, and contain concise information to effectively communicate the project idea.

Maximum slides of PPT :- 10 slides

Pre-Hackathon Preparation

Register before the deadline and ensure you meet the eligibility criteria.
Team size :- 1-4, you can be a lone wolf or with your blasting team members, it's your choice.
Carefully read and understand the theme, rules, and evaluation criteria once provided.
Set up all development tools, dependencies, and required resources in advance.
If participating as a team, plan the project structure and assign roles to team members.
Ensure that you have a stable internet connection, necessary software, and hardware components.
Although we will provide High bandwidth wifi but keep a JIO sim with yourself as JIO sim properly works in our campus.

During the Hackathon

Attend the kickoff session to clarify doubts and finalize your approach.
Start coding and follow best practices for development, including proper documentation and version control (e.g., GitHub).
Seek guidance from mentors and organizers to improve your project.
All development must happen during the hackathon. Bringing pre-developed projects will result in disqualification.
Respect the time limits for each round and ensure progress aligns with submission deadlines.
Participants must adhere to ethical coding practices. Any form of plagiarism or use of third-party pre-built solutions without disclosure will lead to disqualification.

Offline rounds will be conducted within a 12-hour timeframe, including registration, lunch, snacks, project development, and submission. All work must be completed within this duration.


Submission Guidelines

Submissions must include:

Code repository (GitHub/GitLab link with proper README and documentation).
Demo video explaining the working of the project.
Presentation slides detailing the concept, features, and technical aspects.
Deployment link (optional)


Projects must be thoroughly tested for bugs before submission.
Ensure all required files are included and submitted within the given timeframe.
Late submissions will not be accepted under any circumstances.

Judging & Evaluation


Judging in the offline round will be conducted across three key stages:


Pitching Round: Teams will present their ideas, approach, and initial plan to the judges.


Surprise Round: A unique challenge or twist will be introduced, testing adaptability and problem-solving skills.


Final Project Submission: Teams will submit and demonstrate their fully developed project for final evaluation.



Projects will be evaluated based on:

Innovation and originality
Functionality and real-world applicability
User experience (UX/UI) and design
Technical execution and complexity
Presentation and clarity of explanation


Teams must prepare for a Q&A session with judges, explaining their solution in detail.
Live project demonstrations will be required in the offline rounds.

General Rules & Regulations

Participants must be physically present for offline rounds. Remote participation is not allowed.
Join the Official WhatsApp Community: All participants are required to join the official WhatsApp community for important updates, announcements, and coordination. (The link will be shared later.)
All team members must be registered before the deadline. Team changes after registration will not be permitted.
Use of AI-generated code must be disclosed. Failure to do so may result in penalties or disqualification.
Respectful conduct and professionalism are expected throughout the event. Any form of misconduct, including harassment, cheating, or disruption, will lead to immediate disqualification.
Strictly no plagiarism. Any project found copying from existing solutions without proper attribution will be rejected.
Participants must follow all venue rules and regulations as per the organizing institution’s policies.
Power backup, internet connectivity, and technical support will be provided as per availability, but participants should be prepared with alternatives.
The use of third-party APIs and open-source tools is allowed, provided they comply with licensing terms.
The decision of the judges and organizing committee will be final and binding. No appeals or disputes will be entertained.

These guidelines ensure a fair, competitive, and professional environment for all participants. Strict adherence to these rules is mandatory.

title: Speed Coding
organizer: Indian Institute of Information Technology (IIIT), Surat
description:
Speed Coding is a fast-paced competitive programming event designed to test participants’ problem-solving and coding skills under time constraints. Teams of three will compete to solve algorithmic challenges in an ICPC-style format, showcasing their logic, efficiency, and teamwork.
The event consists of two rounds, with the top 8 teams from the first round advancing to the final round. The problems will range from fundamental logic-based puzzles to advanced algorithmic challenges. This offline event will be conducted on the IIIT Surat campus and hosted on Codeforces.
Guidelines:

Eligibility:

Open to all college students.
Teams must consist of exactly three members.


Event Format & Process:

Round 1: All registered teams compete in the preliminary round. The top 8 teams with the highest scores qualify for the final round.
Round 2: The final round where the top 8 teams battle it out to claim victory.
Challenge Structure: Each team will be given three coding problems of varying difficulty.
Platform: The contest will be hosted on Codeforces.
Mode: Offline, conducted on-site at IIIT Surat.



Why Participate?

Test your problem-solving speed and algorithmic efficiency.
Experience an ICPC-style competition format.
Compete against the best coders and showcase your skills.
Win exciting prizes, certificates, and swags!

Are you ready to put your coding skills to the test and compete against the best? Register now and take on the Speed Coding Challenge!

title: National Space Hackathon 2025
description:
PROBLEM STATEMENT AND RULEBOOK: Here.Join this Discord Server for updates and Queries

The National Space Hackathon 2025, organized by IIT Delhi, is a premier national-level competition that challenges students to solve real-world technical problems in space exploration. This is not just a coding contest — it's a platform to think like space engineers, mission planners, and innovators tackling challenges that could arise in future space missions. Participants will have the chance to apply their engineering, programming, and analytical skills to devise solutions that could have practical applications in space missions or astronaut operations.
The problem statement, inspired by real operational challenges in space missions, will be released on March 12, 2025. Participants will have to analyze the problem, research possible solutions, and develop a working website or software tool with the api endpoints defined in the problem statement, develop algorithms, and submit a technical report that effectively addresses the challenge. This is your chance to apply your engineering, coding, and analytical skills to tackle a problem that space missions actually face.
 
The Competition Structure
The hackathon will consist of two rounds:

Preliminary Round (Online): After the problem statement is released, participating teams will work on proposing and developing a solution. This involves building a software tool/ simulation model/webapp or an algorithm, along with a report and a demo video that addresses the challenge. Submissions will be evaluated on a defined rubric (Released with the PS).
Final Round (Online): The top 10 teams from the preliminary round will get a chance to present their solution to an esteemed panel of scientists from ISRO, alongside faculty and researchers from IIT Delhi. The focus will be on innovation, technical soundness, practicality, and potential impact of the solution.

The prize distribution ceremony will be held at IIT Delhi, coinciding with the Global Space Exploration Conference (GLEX 2025), one of the world's most prestigious space exploration events. Prominent space scientists, astronauts, and industry experts from NASA, ISRO, and other global space agencies attending GLEX will visit IIT Delhi during this time. This means participants and winners could get direct exposure to some of the leading minds in space exploration, making the event a truly remarkable platform.
 
Why Should You Participate?
The National Space Hackathon 2025 is more than just a competition — it's an opportunity to:

Solve a real-world space mission challenge and develop a solution that could potentially be applicable to space operations.
Present your work to ISRO scientists and IIT Delhi professors, gaining invaluable feedback from industry leaders.
Attend an award ceremony coinciding with GLEX 2025, where you may have the rare opportunity to interact with astronauts, mission planners, and prominent space scientists visiting from around the world.
Gain national-level recognition for your technical and problem-solving abilities, making this a standout achievement on your academic and professional profile.

 
Are You Ready to Tackle a Real Space Challenge?
This is your chance to work on a space mission challenge that could have real-world implications. Whether you specialize in software development, engineering design, algorithm development, or technical research, this hackathon allows you to test your skills in a high-impact environment.
Form your team, mark your calendars, and get ready to impress some of the brightest minds in the space industry. Who knows — your solution could inspire future space missions.

title: Pass The Baton
description:
Introduction:
Pass The Baton - Quest to Conquer, Relay to Reward.A team-based competitive programming contest, with a unique twist wherein each team member gets a shot at solving the same problem, but without any communication within the team, relying only on the clues left behind by the previous solver. It’s a refreshing take on the traditional programming competition, challenging the participant’s algorithmic prowess, quick thinking and teamwork capabilities.
EVENT FORMAT

The event will consist of an online preliminary round and an on-site final round.
The prelims will be conducted on Codeforces and this will be an ICPC-style contest consisting of 6-8 problems, which must be solved in a 2 hour time frame. The top 20-25 teams from the prelims will qualify to the finals.
The final round will be hosted on Hackerrank and will be conducted on-site. Each of the three team members will be assigned a separate desktop.
The duration of this contest will be 2 hours. For the final round, the entire problem set will be divided into three parts and each team member will get exactly 30 minutes to work on each part, alternately. For example, in the first 30 minutes the three team members will be solving parts A, B and C respectively, in the next 30 minutes they will be solving parts C, A, B respectively, and so forth. Each part will consist of exactly 2 problems. Additionally, a bonus part consisting of 1-2 problems will be available in the last 30 minutes, and unlike previous parts, all 3 teammates can communicate and work together for these problems.Thus, three parts of 30 minutes each and one bonus part of 30 minutes for a total of 2 hours.

EVENT RULES

For Prelims:-
1. All participants must form a team on Codeforces and participate under the same team for the contest.
2. All teams must submit their own solutions for each problem. Any team found guilty of plagiarism will face disqualification.
3. There will be a 20-minute time penalty for each wrong submission. All three team members can make submissions for the problems in any order, but only the first correct submission for a problem will be considered.

For Finals:- 1. Participants can only use the online IDE on Hackerrank platform, while solving the problems. Changing to another tab or window during the contest is strictly prohibited. 2. Team members will be seated away from each other at their own desktops, and will not be able to directly communicate with each other during the contest (except for the bonus part in the last 30 mins). They can only view the code submissions made by the previous team member, for each problem. It is encouraged to leave comments in your code, so that you can share your approach/intended solution more effectively with the next team member. 3. During the bonus part at the last 30 mins, team members will be seated together and will be assigned a single desktop. The team can communicate and solve the problems together during this part. 4. There will be no time penalty for wrong submissions, and only the first correct submission for a problem, made by any of the three team members, will be considered.

For detailed problem statement: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1LMUItjjFEXZ5HwdE-5F_dY6IxIWvQwr3/view

title: Chronoquest: The Cyber Relic Hunt
description:
Chronoquest: The Cyber Relic Hunt
The Beginning of the Hunt

In 2050, a rogue AI named Kronos has infiltrated the world's most advanced technological systems, threatening to erase decades of progress.
The only way to stop it is through a cyber relic hunt, where only the most skilled minds can crack the code, outsmart the system, and reclaim control over the digital world.
You and your team are humanity’s last hope. Armed with expertise in DSA, Cybersecurity, IoT, and Data Science, you must navigate intense challenges, outpace rivals, and prove that innovation can triumph over chaos.

What to Expect

ChronoQuest is not just another tech event—it’s a battle against time and complexity.
Participants will take on real-world challenges across multiple domains, demanding precision, innovation, and adaptability.
The competition unfolds in two thrilling phases, leading to a grand finale where the best minds rise to the top.

What Makes ChronoQuest Unique?

Domain-Specific Challenges – Face problem statements designed to simulate real-world scenarios in DSA, Cybersecurity, IoT, and Data Science.
Beyond Coding – It’s not just about writing code; it’s about solving practical problems that impact the future.
Exclusive Opportunities – Qualifiers gain access to an exclusive interaction session with industry leaders and a tech expo showcasing cutting-edge innovations.
A Competitive Yet Achievable Challenge – Designed for all skill levels, ensuring both beginners and experts find opportunities to excel.

Event Details
Phase 1: Individual Domain Showdown

Each team of four will be split into individuals, with each member assigned one of four game rooms:

DSA & Problem Solving – Optimize algorithms and tackle complex logic.
Cybersecurity – Identify threats and enhance security.
IoT & Infrastructure Manipulation – Solve infrastructure-based challenges.
Data Science – Use DS techniques to analyze and predict outcomes.



Scoring Mechanism:

Faster solutions lead to higher scores.
Individual performances contribute to the team’s overall score.
Only 30 teams with the highest cumulative scores advance to Phase 2.

Rewards:

Top individual performers in each domain will receive exclusive goodies.

Phase 2: The Final Showdown

The 30 qualifying teams will face a mystery challenge, testing their ability to innovate, collaborate, and think beyond the obvious.
The challenge remains undisclosed until the phase begins, adding an element of surprise and excitement.
Teams will be tasked with designing a cutting-edge tech solution under constraints.
Judged by industry experts and a live audience, the best solutions will emerge victorious.

Winning Criteria & Prizes:

Prize Pool of ₹1,00,000, divided into three categories:

Best Innovation & Novelty Based Solution
Best Research-Based Solution
Best Tech-Based Solution



Guidelines & Event Flow
Team Structure

Each team must have exactly 4 members.
Members will compete individually in Phase 1 but contribute to the team’s overall score.

Time Limit & Scoring

Speed matters – Solving challenges faster earns higher scores.
Phase 1 is individual-based, while Phase 2 is a team effort.
Scores will determine who qualifies for the next round.

Rules & Important Notes

Open to all students and tech enthusiasts with a passion for problem-solving.
No prior experience required – just the drive to compete and innovate.
Any form of plagiarism or unethical practices will lead to disqualification.

Step Into the Future of Tech

ChronoQuest is more than just a competition—it’s an opportunity to showcase your talent, gain industry exposure, and be part of a dynamic tech revolution.
Assemble your team, brace yourself for the challenge, and take the leap into the unknown.
Are you ready for the quest?

title: CodeShastra XI

title: SnapSyntax
description:
Introduction:
Snap Syntax – Where memory, mastery, and innovation collide! Think you have what it takes to recreate a web page using just your recall? This thrilling challenge tests your HTML and CSS skills as you and your team race against time to build a webpage from memory—without direct visual reference! With only brief glimpses to guide you, precision and efficiency are key. But beware—a surprise twist awaits, pushing your creativity and innovation to the limit. No templates, no external help—just your skills, strategy, and adaptability. Are you ready for the ultimate web design showdown?
Problem Statement:
In a world dominated by digital presence, the ability to swiftly and accurately recreate a web page from memory is a valuable skill. Snap Syntax seeks to evaluate participants' HTML and CSS proficiency, creativity, and adaptability under pressure. The challenge lies in replicating a given web page within a specified time limit of 2 hours, relying solely on memory, with intermittent glimpses to refine designs.
Rules:

Participants will begin by observing an initial web page, which they must recreate from memory using HTML and CSS.
The duration of the event will be 2 hours. The first visual will be shown at the beginning of the event for 1 min. At the end of each hour, a one minute visual will be provided to the teams.
The challenge unfolds without direct visual reference, requiring participants to rely solely on memory for layout, elements, and design nuances.
The use of external resources, pre-existing templates, or collaboration with others is strictly prohibited.(although reading of documentation for syntax or getting use case, if needed is fine)
Clicking a photo of the page is strictly prohibited but the participants can draw the image of the website on paper.

title: Duality Extended
description:
Duality is an offline event where teams compete in a series of DSA-themed challenges, testing both theoretical knowledge and practical problem-solving skills. With each stage featuring unique algorithm-based tasks, participants must think critically, optimize solutions, and collaborate effectively to progress. The event offers a great opportunity to enhance coding efficiency, master algorithmic techniques, and gain hands-on competitive programming experience.
Eligibility:

Open to all undergraduate and postgraduate students.
Participants must form teams of 2-3 members.
Individual participants will be paired with others if necessary.
Prior knowledge of data structures and algorithms is recommended but not mandatory.

Inter-College & Inter-Specialization Participation:

Inter-college team members are not allowed. All team members must be from the same institution.
Inter-specialization team members are allowed within the same institution, encouraging collaboration across different fields of study.

Format of the Event:

The event consists of multiple rounds, each with a set number of problem statements.
Teams will be given a fixed time to solve the problems in each round.
The difficulty level increases with each round, requiring teams to adapt and apply more advanced problem-solving techniques as they progress.
Each round will eliminate lower-ranking teams, ensuring that only the best-performing teams advance further.

Number of Questions & Duration:

Each round consists of a predefined number of problem statements, carefully designed to test different aspects of DSA knowledge.
The duration of each round is already mentioned in the round details
Teams must submit their solutions within the stipulated time. Late submissions will not be accepted under any circumstances.

Code Submission & Evaluation:

Participants must submit their solutions through the designated platform.
Solutions will be evaluated based on correctness, efficiency, and adherence to the problem constraints.
Partial points may be awarded for incomplete but partially correct solutions.
Code must be well-structured and free from syntax errors to be considered for evaluation.

Rules:

Team Formation: Teams must consist of 2-3 members. Individual participants will be paired with others to form teams if necessary.
Submission Ranking: In case of a tie, the participant/team with the earliest submission will rank higher.
Plagiarism & Fair Play: Any form of plagiarism, external assistance, or code-sharing is strictly prohibited. Teams found violating this will face immediate disqualification.
Originality of Solutions: All code and solutions must be written by the participants during the contest. Pre-written or externally sourced code is not allowed.
Technical Issues: No additional time will be provided for technical difficulties unless there is a platform-wide issue affecting all participants.
Communication Restrictions: Teams are not allowed to discuss problems with other teams during the event. All discussions must be within the team.
Use of Online Resources: Participants are strictly prohibited from using online forums, code repositories, or any external resources for assistance.

Disqualification Criteria:

Engaging in any unfair means such as sharing solutions or using pre-written code.
Failing to submit solutions within the given time limits.
Disrespecting event organizers, volunteers, or fellow participants.
Using unauthorized tools, scripts, or automated bots to solve problems.

Tie-Breaking Rules:

In case of a tie between participants or teams, the ranking will be determined based on the following priority:
Total Score: The team with the higher cumulative score will be ranked higher.
Fastest Submission Time: If multiple teams have the same score, the team that submitted their final correct solution the earliest will be ranked higher.
Tie-Breaker Problem:
If a tie still persists after applying the above criteria, a sudden-death challenge problem will be introduced.
The first team to submit a correct solution for this problem will win the tie-breaker and secure a higher rank.
The sudden-death problem will be designed to test quick thinking and precision under pressure.

Free Transportation will be provided from IFFCO Chowk Metro Station to and from BML Munjal University Campus, Gurugram

title: Cursed Code - Ctf
organizer: Maharaja Agrasen Institute of Technology (MAIT), New Delhi
description:
Join Whatsapp Group Is Mandatory : Link
About the Event:

Registration: Free

What to Expect?

title: Operation Cipher Shadows
description:
A Cybersecurity Competition
Operation Cipher Shadows is a cybersecurity competition designed to test participants' skills in general cybersecurity. Compete in a dynamic, challenge-based environment where problem-solving and technical skills are key.
Rules and Regulations
Team Size

Teams can have up to 4 members.

Flag Sharing

All flags will follow the format: shadowCTF{flag_name}, unless stated otherwise.
Sharing of flags, solutions, or challenge write-ups is STRICTLY PROHIBITED.
Teams must independently solve all challenges. Collaboration outside of official team members will be considered cheating.
If any team is caught leaking/sharing flags, they will face instant disqualification.
Post-event solution sharing is allowed, but during the competition, it is strictly forbidden.

Challenge Dependencies

Certain challenges will only unlock after solving prerequisite ones.
Tampering with or attempting unauthorized access to locked challenges will result in penalties or disqualification.

Limited Attempts

Some challenges have a limited number of attempts before they are locked.
These challenges will not be reopened unless an issue is confirmed by the Admin team.

Communication Guidelines

Use Discord for Queries: All clarifications and discussions must happen in the official Discord server.
Do Not DM Admins or Challenge Authors: Direct messaging is not allowed unless explicitly permitted.
Use Designated Channels: Queries must be posted in appropriate channels to maintain fairness and transparency.
Respect & Courtesy: Treat all participants, organizers, and admins with respect.

Abuse, harassment, or unsportsmanlike behavior will not be tolerated and may lead to disqualification.



Technical Rules

No Malicious Activity:

Intentional attacks on competition servers, DoS attempts, or exploiting unintended vulnerabilities will result in immediate disqualification and possible banning from future events.


No Unauthorized Scanning:

The use of automated tools (e.g., Burp Suite Intruder, SQLmap, Hydra) is strictly forbidden, unless explicitly allowed in a challenge description.
Violations will lead to penalties or disqualification.



Evaluation Criteria

The competition will be evaluated based on CTFd rankings.
To be eligible for final rankings, teams must be registered on Unstop as well.

title: ROS Navigator Challenge
description:
ROS Navigator Challenge – Detailed Competition Opportunity
Introduction & Overview:The ROS Navigator Challenge is a robotics simulation competition designed to push your ROS skills and algorithmic ingenuity to the next level. Participants are tasked with programming a bot to autonomously navigate through a dynamically generated maze in a Gazebo simulation environment. The primary objective is to reach the maze’s centre in the least number of steps possible, all while abiding by strict sensor constraints and simulation rules. This competition not only tests your coding prowess but also evaluates how well you can design an efficient navigation algorithm under real-time constraints. As the tagline goes, “Code, Navigate, Conquer!”
Eligibility & Team Composition:

Eligibility: Open to all students making it an inclusive platform for emerging talent in robotics.
Team Size: Each team may consist of a minimum of 1 and a maximum of 3 members.
Team Flexibility: Cross-college teams are allowed, which means you can collaborate with peers from different institutions. This encourages a blend of diverse ideas and expertise in solving complex problems.
Inter-Specialization: Teams can comprise members from different specializations as long as they meet the competition criteria.
Registration: Registration is mandatory and must be completed by 5 April 2025. On successful registration, participants will receive a GitHub repository via email containing the simulation setup, the base algorithm, and other necessary resources. 

Competition Structure & Format:
Round 1: Method Summary Submission:
In the first stage, teams are required to submit a detailed method summary that outlines their proposed approach for navigating the maze. This document should include:

Algorithm Explanation: A clear description of the navigation strategy, including any algorithms or heuristics you intend to use.
Approach Feasibility: An assessment of the expected performance of your solution, backed by preliminary reasoning or simulation data if available.
Innovation Factor: Creativity in tackling the maze’s dynamic challenges is highly valued.This round is crucial as it filters the most promising submissions; only teams that demonstrate a well-thought-out approach will qualify for the second round.

Round 2: Maze Navigation Challenge:
Qualified teams move on to a live simulation challenge where a random maze is generated in the Gazebo environment. Here, you must execute the navigation algorithm developed in Round 1. Key points include:

Attempts: Each team is granted two attempts to solve the maze. The best attempt, measured by the fewest steps to reach the centre, is used for final scoring.
Time Constraint: In each attempt, if the bot remains stuck for more than 30 seconds, the attempt will be marked invalid. This ensures that your algorithm is not only efficient but also robust in handling unforeseen obstacles.
Scoring System:

The primary metric is the number of steps taken by the bot to reach the centre of the maze.
In the event of a tie, the tie-breaker will be determined by the lowest total net steps across both attempts, ensuring a fair assessment of overall performance.



Sensor Constraints & Technical Guidelines:

Allowed Sensors: Teams are permitted to use sensors such as LiDAR, proximity sensors, wheel odometry, and IMU. These sensors must be utilized in a manner that does not compromise the challenge’s integrity.
Prohibited Sensors: Any sensor that can provide a top-down view of the maze or enables the bot to “cheat” by seeing beyond the maze walls is strictly forbidden.
Simulation Integrity: Any attempt to modify the simulation environment or manually interfere during runtime will lead to immediate disqualification. This rule enforces a level playing field and ensures that every team competes under the same conditions.

Code of Conduct & Disqualification Criteria:Maintaining integrity and fairness is paramount. All participants are expected to abide by a strict code of conduct:

Fair Play: Use only the authorized sensors and follow the guidelines set out in the rulebook.
Documentation: Timely submission of the required method summary and adherence to deadlines are mandatory.
Disqualification: Breaching any of the rules, such as using unauthorized sensors, altering the simulation environment, or failing to submit documentation, will result in disqualification. This ensures that all competitors are judged solely on their technical and problem-solving skills.

Additional Competition Details:

Innovation & Strategy: Emphasis is placed on creative problem-solving and the efficient execution of your navigation strategy.
Evaluation: A panel of judges will assess submissions based on feasibility, innovation, and overall performance in the simulation round.
Contact & Support: For any queries or further assistance, you can reach out directly to the event heads:

Parth Sachdeva: +91 9149663246, 2023ucs0105@iitjammu.ac.in
Purushartha Gupta: +91 9369573768, 2023uce0062@iitjammu.ac.in



This extended and comprehensive competition description aims to cover all aspects of the challenge—from eligibility and rules to scoring and disqualification criteria—ensuring that potential participants are fully informed and prepared. Good luck, and may your code navigate the maze to triumph

title: Prosperity
description:
What is Prosperity?
Prosperity is a 15-day-long trading challenge happening somewhere in a near-utopian future. You’re in control of an island in an archipelago, and your goal is to bring your island to prosperity. You do so by earning as many SeaShells as possible, the main currency in the archipelago. The more SeaShells you earn, the more your island will prosper.
During your 15 days on the island, your trading abilities will be tested through a variety of trading challenges. It’s up to you to develop a successful trading strategy. You will be working on a Python script to handle algorithmic trades on your behalf. Every round also presents a manual trading challenge; a one-off challenge that is separate from your algorithmic trading and could yield some additional profits. Your success depends on both these algorithmic and manual trades.
Take a deep breath and smell the opportunities drifting by with the ocean breeze. It’s up to you to seize those opportunities and lead your island into prosperity. At times, it will be challenging, hard even, but for those who know how to work the market to their favor, the reward will be bountiful.
Prosperity Storyline:
The main character in the game is a cockatoo who lives in the archipelago. Besides a cockatoo, he is also the news anchor for Tropical TV. Every round, he’ll give you the latest headlines, all you need to know to progress in the game. The news broadcasts from Tropical TV will play an important role during our 15-day trading challenge. The cockatoo will give a short update on what happened in the previous round before he discloses this round’s assignment and tradable goods. During the trading season, you’ll meet all kinds of interesting characters. Some from within our own archipelago and some that we consider our neighbours. All of them have their own unique story. You should definitely keep your ears peeled for those stories because every real trading tycoon knows that within every story, there is an opportunity to be found. You just have to know how to turn that compelling story into a profitable strategy.
Rounds:
The 15 days of simulation of Prosperity are divided into 5 rounds with each round lasting 72 hours. At the end of every round - before the timer runs out - all teams will have to submit their algorithmic and manual trades to be processed. The algorithms will then participate in a full day of trading against the Prosperity trading bots. Note that all algorithms are trading separately, there is no interaction between the algorithms of different players. When a new round starts, the results of the previous round will be disclosed and the leaderboard will be updated accordingly. During the game, you can always visit previous rounds in the dashboard, to review information and results. But once a round is closed, you can no longer change your submitted trades for that round. When round 5 ends, the final results will be processed and the winner of the Prosperity trading challenge will be announced.
Algorithmic Trading:
Every round contains an algorithmic trading challenge. You will have 72 hours to submit your (final) Python program. When the round ends, the last successfully processed submission will be locked in and processed for results.

Tutorial: February 24, 1530 hrs → April 7, 1530 hrs
Round 1: April 7, 1530 hrs → April 10, 1530 hrs
Round 2: April 10, 1530 hrs → April 13, 1530 hrs
Round 3: April 13, 1530 hrs → April 16, 1530 hrs
Round 4: April 16, 1530 hrs → April 19, 1530 hrs
Round 5: April 19, 1530 hrs → April 22, 1530 hrs

All rounds contain a manual trading challenge. Just like the algorithmic challenge, manual trading challenges last 72 hours to submit your (final) trade. When the round ends, the last submission will be locked in and processed for results. During the tutorial round, manual trading is inactive. Note that manual trades have no effect on your algorithmic trade and can be seen as separate challenges to gain additional profits.
Guidelines:

It’s a 15-day live trading simulation (don’t worry, it’s not full-time).
You can participate as a lone wolf or in a team size of up to 5 members.
Join fully remotely, from anywhere, alone or in a team.

title: Idea Challenge on Peace Welfare 2025
description:
2025 Peace Welfare Challenge is Organized by Ganesan and Incubation Center, Chennai- Calling Innovators, Problem Solvers and Start-ups. Applications close on 1st April 2025.
The Ganesan Incubation & Entrepreneurship Centre (GIEC) is an integral part of Vinayaka Mission and Research Foundation, located at the Paiyanoor Campus. GIEC’s mission is to empower focused and passionate individuals by providing them with the platform to apply their knowledge and drive economic growth and intellectual capital for Venture development.
Sri Vishnu Mohan Foundation under the aegis of Sri Gnana Advaitha Peetam is organizing the 10th Conference of Annual Peace and Reconciliation Conference 2025 in the Second week of April 2025 at Arupadai Veedu Institute of Technology, Paiyanoor, Chennai.  As part of the conference the foundation will conduct programs to bring a framework of justice for enhancing societal and individual peace. The Foundation applies a values-based approach to the universal commitment of peaceful living.
Driving this years’ theme is “Peace is born of justice”. In view of this Ganesan Incubation and Entrepreneurship Development Center under Vinayaka Mission Research Foundation-DU is inviting science, technology, business or legal innovations on enhancing Peace to societal and Individual.
We invite you to present your innovative ideas, whether they are in science, technology, business, or law, that can enhance peace at the societal and individual levels. Proposals are welcome under the following categories:
Few Suggestive themes are provided in the Application Link but is not limited or inclusive. Innovators can chooose their own idea that can improve Peace and welfare in the Society 

Technologies improving transparent governance, social, economic and political conflicts, peace building
Education imparting emotional intelligence or through curriculum innovation
Legal aid platforms
Healthcare in crisis or for displaced populations
social development creating community-driven initiatives for rebuilding infrastructure, including schools, hospitals, and public spaces, to restore a sense of normalcy and resilience in post-conflict areas.

Eligibility: 
Category A: For Individual Innovators (Students pursuing any discipline)
Category B: Startups working on above related themes with a prototype or Student/Faculty Teams with identified skill sets for the idea.

Innovations in technology in its core product or service (or)
Innovations in business model, or distribution model

Application Process: Applicant must submit the details in the Google link provided before 1st April 2025. The completed pitch deck should also be enclosed in the prescribed format.
Shortlisted applications will be invited for the pitching session on a scheduled date before the conference to GIEC Chennai Campus. Details will only be sent to the shortlisted candidates.
Top 3 participants in category A and B will be awarded on the Annual Peace conference and the finalists in the Category B will further be provided with a seed support Grant subject to meeting the incubation conditions at GIEC .

title: Hack36 8.0
organizer: Motilal Nehru National Institute of Technology, Allahabad
description:
Hack36 is the annual national-level hackathon organized by the Computer Coding Club (CC) of MNNIT Allahabad. It is a 36-hour-long coding marathon where developers, designers, and innovators from across the country come together to solve real-world problems using technology. The event is known for its intense competition, collaborative spirit, and high-quality projects, offering participants a unique chance to learn, build, and network with like-minded individuals.
Why Participate in Hack36?
Hack36 is more than just a hackathon; it’s a launchpad for young developers looking to showcase their skills, collaborate with industry experts, and gain real-world experience. Participants can choose from problem statements spanning AI, Blockchain, IoT, FinTech, EdTech, and Cybersecurity, or work on their own innovative ideas.
For Regular Updates follow us on:
Instagram - https://www.instagram.com/hack36_/
Discord - https://discord.gg/wNRtaSHMP4
X - https://x.com/hack36mnnit/

Opportunities at Hack36:
1. Internship & Job Offers:
Hack36 provides a golden opportunity for students to connect with top tech companies, startups, and recruiters. Many participants secure internships and full-time job offers based on their performance. Sponsors and industry mentors actively scout for talent, making it an excellent platform for career growth.
2. Industry Exposure & Mentorship:
Participants get access to mentorship from industry professionals and academicians, helping them refine their ideas and improve their technical skills. Direct interactions with leading engineers, developers, and tech leaders provide insights into industry trends and best practices.
3. Networking & Community Building:
Hack36 is a hub for networking with fellow coders, designers, and tech enthusiasts. It is a great opportunity to form connections, collaborate on future projects, and become part of the larger developer community. Many participants find long-term teammates for future hackathons and open-source projects.
4. Hands-on Experience with Latest Technologies:
Participants gain practical exposure to cutting-edge tools, APIs, and cloud platforms provided by sponsors like Google, Microsoft, Amazon, and GitHub. This hands-on experience boosts their technical knowledge and problem-solving abilities.
5. Prizes, Recognition & Post-Hackathon Support:
Winning teams receive cash prizes, swags, and startup incubation opportunities. Some projects also get continued support in the form of funding, technical assistance, and mentorship, allowing them to grow beyond the hackathon.
Structure of the Event:
The event spans 36 hours, divided into key phases:

Registration & Selection: Teams (2-4 members) are shortlisted based on their problem-solving approach.
Hackathon Kickoff: Opening ceremony, problem statements, and mentorship sessions.
Development & Mid-Evaluation: Teams build their prototypes with guidance from mentors.
Final Submission & Judging: Projects are evaluated on innovation, technical complexity, and impact.
Demo & Awards: Winners present their solutions and receive rewards.

Conclusion
Hack36 is a life-changing experience for tech enthusiasts, providing them with career-defining opportunities, industry exposure, and a platform to innovate. Whether you’re a beginner or an experienced coder, Hack36 is the perfect place to showcase your talent, learn from peers, and build something impactful.

title: ByteVerse 7.0 Hackathon
description:
ByteVerse Hackathon - NIT Patna's Annual Technical Hackathon
Welcome to ByteVerse, NIT Patna’s flagship annual technical hackathon! This is a 30-hour online hackathon where students from various colleges come together to build innovative solutions to real-world problems.

Participants can form teams of up to 4 members.

Hackathon Format:

There will be a mid-evaluation round where teams present their progress.

Rules

title: Code-Wars 3.0
organizer: Nitte Meenakshi Institute of Technology (NMIT), Yelahanka
description:
CODE-WARS 3.0
The event consists of three rounds, each designed to test different programming skills, including speed, efficiency, and debugging abilities.
*Note - All teams need to be physically present at the venue
Round 1: Trivia Triumph

Objective:

Participants will take part in a quiz hosted on Menti, an interactive quiz platform.
The questions will be related to coding, algorithms, logical reasoning, or general computer science knowledge.


Judgment Criteria:

Speed & Accuracy: The fastest and most correct responses will be rewarded with higher points.
Since Menti quizzes are real-time and interactive, the earlier a participant answers correctly, the more points they get.



Round 2: Byte-Size Battle

Objective:

Each team will be given a programming problem to solve.
The main challenge is to write a correct solution using the fewest characters of code possible.



Additional Details:

Teams will be pre-planned and paired against each other based on the language they choose to use.
This means teams will face one-on-one competition in each matchup and only the winner goes to the finale.
The goal is to write a concise yet functional solution.

Judgment Criteria:

The team with the fewest characters of correct code wins the matchup.
If two teams have the same number of characters, the winner will be determined by:

Earlier submission time.
Execution time and space efficiency, as calculated by the coding platform.



Round 3: Bug Buster 

Objective:

Participants will be given buggy code (code with errors or logical flaws) and will be required to fix all errors as quickly as possible.
The focus is on debugging efficiency, not writing fresh code.


Additional Details:

Teams will also get a 3-minute window to inject bugs into an opponent’s code.
This adds a strategic sabotage element, requiring teams to be smart about introducing new bugs while ensuring they can still debug efficiently.


Judgment Criteria:

The first team to fully debug their code wins.
The second team to finish is the runner-up, and so on.
If multiple teams complete debugging around the same time, the winner will be decided based on:

Time is taken to fix all errors.
Complexity and correctness of debugging.





Fair Play & Violation Consequences:

Plagiarism, unauthorized collaboration, or external help → Disqualification.
Disrupting another team (outside of Round 3 bug injection) → Immediate elimination.
Unfair debugging (e.g., deleting code instead of fixing) → Penalty points or disqualification.

Rules & Regulations:
General Rules:

Team Composition: Maximum of 2 members per team; solo participation is allowed.
Elimination & Qualification:

Round 1: The top 50% of teams (max 20 teams) qualify for Round 2.
Round 2: Teams face pre-planned matchups; winners advance, losers are eliminated.
Round 3: The team that fully debugs their code first wins, followed by runner-ups.


Use of External Resources:

No AI tools, internet assistance, or plagiarism.
No external help or code copying.


Conduct & Sportsmanship:

Any form of cheating, plagiarism, or misconduct results in disqualification.
Teams must respect judges, organizers, and fellow participants.
No interference with other teams’ work (except bug injection in Round 3).



Final Notes:

Judges’ decisions are final and non-negotiable.
Any unexpected disputes will be resolved by event organizers.
Teams should maintain integrity, play fair, and enjoy the challenge.

title: Code Auction
organizer: Department of Computer Science (DoCS), University of Delhi (DU)
description:
Event Description : 
Code Auction is a unique and exciting technical event that combines strategic bidding with competitive coding, where teams must bid on coding questions within a fixed budget before solving them to secure a top position. It offers participants the opportunity to showcase their coding skills while employing tactical decision-making through an auction system.
The event aims to test participants' coding proficiency and their ability to make strategic bids to maximize their success.
Event Structure:
The event will consist of two primary rounds:

Auction Round
Coding Round

 Auction Round:

Teams must consist of 3 to 4 members.
Out of these members, 2 members will be responsible for coding, and the remaining 1 or 2 members will handle the auctioning.
Each team will receive an initial purse of 120 points (bidding currency).
A set of challenging coding questions will be presented for auction in three categories:

Easy: Base price 30 points, each bid increases price by 15 points
Medium: Base price 20 points, each bid increases price by 10 points
Hard: Base price 15 points, each bid increases price by 5 points


Teams must bid to purchase the questions using their points.
The bid amount will be deducted from the team’s purse upon successful purchase of a question.
Each team must purchase exactly 3 questions to qualify for the next round. Teams cannot purchase more or fewer than 3 questions, and failing to secure exactly 3 will result in elimination.
If a team is unable to purchase 3 questions due to insufficient points, they will be eliminated.
Atleast one easy question is Compulsory to purchase.

 Coding Round:

The coding round will be conducted immediately after the auction.
The team members who were not involved in the auction will be responsible for solving the purchased questions.
Teams will be evaluated based on:

The correctness of the solutions.
The time taken to solve the problems.


Each problem category will have a different weightage to ensure a balanced competition. The point distribution is designed to reflect the relative difficulty of each category while maintaining fairness across all possible question combinations.

Easy: 20 points
Medium: 35 points
Hard: 40 points


In case multiple teams solve all their questions correctly, ranking will be based on the completion time.
The top 3 teams with the best performance will be declared winners.

Guidelines:

Open to UG/PG Students of all Colleges and all Courses
Total Duration of Competition will be 3 hours (Auction [2 hours] + Coding [1 hour] Round)
There will be 3 problems related to coding , Data Structures and Algorithms 

Event Rules:

Each team must have 3 to 4 members.
The auctioning team members cannot participate in the coding round.
The initial bidding purse is 120 points.
Each question will have a base price, and teams must bid to acquire questions.
A team must successfully purchase at least 3 questions to proceed to the coding round.
Failure to buy at least 3 questions will result in elimination. Teams should plan their bids strategically, as no rebidding opportunities will be provided once their purse is exhausted.
The coding round will be evaluated based on accuracy and completion time.
The top 3 teams will be awarded prizes based on their performance.

title: Chip-o-Mania
description:
Event Description
Step into the world of Chip-o-Mania, a dynamic hackathon and idea presentation event where cutting-edge VLSI (Very Large Scale Integration) challenges await. Guided by Digital VLSI Club professors and industry experts, you’ll tackle real-world problems and propose innovative solutions backed by software simulations. Show off your creativity, problem-solving skills, and technical expertise as you help shape the future of semiconductor technology. Ready to push the limits of what’s possible? Let’s revolutionize VLSI together!
Event Rules

Round 1: Abstract Submission (Online Screening)
Teams will submit an abstract (max. 4 pages) outlining their approach to the given problem statement. Format can be PDF, Doc or PPT
The problem Statement would be in the domain of Analog, Digital VLSI or Mixed Signal. The Problem Statement is live.
The abstract should include a problem analysis, proposed methodology, tools/software to be used, and expected outcomes with relevant block diagrams and simulation results using EDA tools like Cadence, Synopsys, Xilinx Vivado, Iverilog, Mentor Graphics, etc.
Any Simulations or Proposals based on direct implementation on a Raspberry Pi or Arduino will be eliminated. However, implementations based on FPGAs would be credited. Teams can use online FPGA simulators or use in-built simulators in Xilinx Vivado for Digital ideas for Chip-o-Mania.
Top 10 teams will be shortlisted for the next round.
Round 2: Onsite Idea Presentation
Shortlisted teams will work on their proposed solutions and develop software-based simulations using EDA tools such as Cadence, Synopsys, Xilinx Vivado, Iverilog, Mentor Graphics, etc.
Each team will be allotted 15 minutes for idea presentation and/or any live simulation of results.
Teams will present their ideas and simulation results to a panel of industry experts and professors who will judge the teams.

Problem Statement: Chip-o-Mania Problem Statement
For detailed competition structure: Link

title: Web Hackathon
description:
General Rules:

Participants can register individually or in teams (maximum of 4 members per team).
The hackathon theme and problem statements will be announced at the start of the event.
All development must take place within the 24-hour duration—pre-existing projects are not allowed.
Use of third-party libraries, APIs, and frameworks is allowed but must be disclosed.
AI-generated code/assets are permitted only if disclosed and properly credited.

 Team Formation:

Each team must designate a team leader for communication with organizers.
Participants cannot be part of multiple teams.
Teams cannot merge or split after registration.

 Development & Coding Guidelines:

Original work only—projects must be built from scratch during the hackathon.
Pre-existing boilerplate code (like UI templates) can be used, but must be disclosed.
Plagiarism is strictly prohibited—any detected plagiarism will result in immediate disqualification.
Offensive, illegal, or unethical content is strictly not allowed.
Submissions must be functional—non-working prototypes will not be considered.

 Submission Requirements:

Teams must submit their projects before the deadline.
Submission must include:

Working demo (hosted link or locally runnable build)
GitHub repository (with clear documentation)
Presentation slides (max 5 slides) explaining the idea, tech stack, and implementation
Team details and roles

Late submissions will not be accepted.

 Judging Criteria:
Projects will be evaluated based on:

Innovation & Creativity (20%) – Uniqueness of the idea
Functionality & Execution (30%) – Working demo, responsiveness, and usability
Technical Implementation (25%) – Code quality, scalability, and best practices
UI/UX Design (15%) – User-friendly interface and visual appeal
Adherence to Theme (10%) – Relevance to the given challenge

 Code of Conduct:

Respect all participants, mentors, and organizers.
Collaboration is encouraged, but no external help or outsourcing is allowed.
Hacking, cheating, or any form of unethical behavior will result in disqualification.
If an issue arises, teams should report to the organizers immediately.

 Hardware & Internet Usage:

Participants must use their own laptops/devices—external servers can be used if disclosed.
No DDoS attacks, unauthorized API abuse, or network manipulation allowed.
Organizers are not responsible for hardware failures or lost progress—backup your work frequently.

 Intellectual Property & Rights:

Participants own their projects, but organizers reserve the right to showcase the work for promotional purposes.
If using third-party APIs, ensure compliance with their licensing terms.

 Prizes & Recognition:

Winners will be announced after final judging.
Any disputes regarding judging will be resolved at the organizers’ discretion.

By participating, you agree to abide by these rules. Failure to comply may lead to disqualification.
Complete Details Will Be Announced Soon.

title: CodeBid
organizer: MKSSS's Cummins College of Engineering for Women (CCOEW), Pune
description:
CodeBid - Code Auction is a thrilling web replication challenge with a strategic twist! Participants will be shown a premium-quality website for 2-3 minutes and must replicate it as accurately as possible within a limited timeframe. But there’s a catch—teams must strategically bid their points in an auction-based system to gain extra development time or useful code snippets.
It’s a test of time management, technical skills, and strategic decision-making!
Rounds:
Round 1: Web Development and AI/ML MCQs
This will be an MCQ-based elimination round testing participants on Web Development and AI/ML concepts, with 20 questions to be solved in 20 minutes.
Round 2: Offline CodeBid
Phase 1: The Time Auction

 Every team will be given a fixed number of points at the start.
 Teams bid for extra development time using their points.
 If a team bids higher, they get more time but lose points that could be used later for code snippets.

Phase 2: The Web Development Challenge

 Teams will start replicating the website using their chosen development time.
 Throughout the 3-hour challenge, code snippets will appear on a screen for a few seconds.
 If a team finds a snippet useful, they can bid their remaining points to obtain it.
 Teams must carefully balance their points, development time, and coding resources.

Slots and Duration:

Slot 1: 8:00 AM to 12:00 Noon
 Slot 2: 12:30 PM to 4:30 PM

Eligibility:

 All undergraduate college students are eligible, irrespective of their branch, class, and field of study.
Intercollege Teams not allowed (All members to be from the same college)

Entry Requirements:

 The registration fee is non-refundable.
 The event will be conducted in two slots.

Judging Criteria:

  Website Accuracy: The team whose website most closely resembles the original wins.
  Remaining Points: Teams with higher remaining points will have an advantage.
  Efficient Time & Resource Utilization: How effectively teams bid for time and code snippets will be considered.

Guidelines:

  Strictly individual team efforts – no external help or collaboration.
  Cheating or use of unauthorized tools (AI tools, code generators, etc.) will lead to disqualification.
  Teams must submit their final website within their allotted time.
  The organizers’ decisions will be final in all competition matters.

title: Colossus 2.O
organizer: Dr Ambedkar Institute of Technology, Bengaluru
description:

Get ready for an electrifying 24-hour coding marathon at Colossus 2025, hosted by the technical club of Dr. Ambedkar Institute of Technology, Bengaluru! Focuses on integrating advanced technologies with healthcare to improve patient care, diagnostics, medical management, and overall accessibility of health services.

Aims to revolutionize agriculture by leveraging technology to enhance productivity, optimize resource usage, ensure food security, and create sustainable farming practices.

title: Uncode
description:
Event Description
Put your problem-solving skills to the test in Uncode, a mind-bending challenge where logic and pattern recognition take center stage! As part of Srijan'25, this event challenges teams to analyze given inputs and outputs, uncover the hidden pattern, and write code that replicates it.
Gather your team of 1-2 members and prepare for an exhilarating two-round competition. The online Prelims will test your ability to decipher patterns and think algorithmically, with the best teams advancing to the offline Finals, where you'll face even more intriguing challenges.
Think you have what it takes to crack the code? Join Uncode and prove your pattern-solving prowess!
Event Rules

The contest will consist of a number of problems of increasing difficulty.
Each question will have a specific input and output format which will be specified in the question itself. The contestant will have to decode the logic used in the question to generate the output for each input.
You will be required to write a program (in C/C++/Python/Java) that behaves indistinguishably from the given executable for all inputs in the domain.
Teams indulging in plagiarism will be disqualified.

title: GDG - Prabal 2025
description:
Prabal - A Hackathon by GDG on Campus SGU
"Hack it, till you make it!"  
Prabal is a hackathon organized by the Google Developer Group (GDG) at Sanjay Ghodawat University (SGU). This event brings together innovative minds to solve real-world problems through technology, fostering creativity, teamwork, and technical expertise with a gamified approach.  
Event Structure
Offline Hackathon (On SGU Campus)
A 40-hour hackathon held at Sanjay Ghodawat University, where participants will compete to develop innovative solutions.  
Problem Statement Release:

Problem statements will be provided five days before the hackathon start date.  
Participants can begin developing their Minimum Viable Product (MVP) as soon as the problem statements are released.  

Activities:

Gamified elements to maintain a competitive spirit throughout the event.  
Participants will be divided into four houses (Targaryen, Stark, Lannister, and Baratheon), competing for exclusive swags in their respective houses.
Each house will have its own leaderboard, and the top three scorers from each house will be awarded swags.  

Project Submission:

Teams must submit their projects within the stipulated 40-hour timeframe.  

Evaluation Criteria:  Judges will evaluate projects based on:  

Originality and Innovation
Creativity and Technical Implementation
Scalability and Practicality
Potential Impact
Teams must present a working prototype/demo at the end of the hackathon.  

Participation Details

title: ACM TCET Code Warz '25
organizer: Thakur College of Engineering and Technology (TCET), Mumbai
description:
ACM TCET Code Warz '25 – Competitive Programming Competition
The ACM chapter of Thakur College of Engineering presents Code Warz '25, a two-day online competitive programming event scheduled for April 4th and 5th, 2025. Designed to challenge and inspire coders of all levels, the competition features a diverse set of coding problems that test logic, efficiency, and problem-solving skills.
Event Structure
Each day includes four problems:

Three Standard Problems:

Easy (20 points): Tests foundational concepts like loops and conditionals.
Medium (30 points): Requires knowledge of data structures or optimization techniques.
Hard (50 points): Involves advanced topics such as dynamic programming or graph theory.


Problem of the Day (PotD) (50 points): A unique, creative challenge designed to encourage innovative thinking, with varying difficulty.

Maximum Score Per Day: 150 points (100 from standard problems + 50 from the PotD). Points are awarded only for correct solutions.
Prizes
Day 1

Top-scoring individual: ₹2000
First (or fastest) PotD solver: ₹500

Day 2

Top-scoring individual: ₹3000
First (or fastest) PotD solver: ₹500

The competition emphasizes both accuracy and speed, providing an engaging platform for participants to showcase their coding skills and algorithmic problem-solving abilities. Whether you're a beginner or an experienced programmer, Code Warz '25 promises a challenging and rewarding experience

title: Tech Trap
description:
Tech Trap: The Ultimate Escape Room Challenge
Tech Trap is not just an escape room—it’s a battle of wits, logic, and technical expertise. Designed for those who dare to think fast and solve smart, this immersive challenge will put your coding, problem-solving, and teamwork skills to the test.
Locked in a high-stakes, tech-themed environment, participants must navigate through a series of mind-bending puzzles covering algorithms, cybersecurity, and hardware to break free—before time runs out.
Will you decode the secrets, crack the codes, and escape in time? Or will you be trapped in the loop forever?
Event Overview:

Date & Time: 19th April 2025
Location: BML Munjal University
Time Limit: 45 minutes per challenge room
Team Size: 2-4 members per team

Flow of Activity:
Participants will advance through two thrilling escape rooms, each presenting unique challenges:

Logical Labyrinth

A twisted maze of logic and riddles where only keen minds and sharp instincts can unravel hidden messages.
Quick thinking and teamwork are essential to progress.
The final twist may change everything.


Code Breaker

A cryptography challenge where teams must decode messages hidden in physical objects.
Uses binary, hexadecimal, and octal codes to find the right key.
The ultimate clue is around you.



Rules & Guidelines:

Team Size: 2-4 members per team
One Hint Per Team – Use it wisely
No Electronic Devices Allowed – Only brainpower
No Exiting the Puzzle Room – Once inside, you must solve to escape
Do Not Alter the Room Setup – Props and furniture must remain untouched
Time Limit: 45 minutes per room to solve the puzzles and progress
All rooms are locked via digital locks – The only way out is through
Violating rules or unsportsmanlike behavior may lead to disqualification

Why Participate?

Test Your Tech & Logic Skills – Push your problem-solving abilities to the limit
Hands-On Experience – Apply cryptography, algorithms, and lateral thinking in real-time
Teamwork & Strategy – Work under pressure and solve puzzles as a unit
Bragging Rights & Recognition – Prove you’re the ultimate escape artist

Are You Ready to Escape?
This is your chance to prove your skills, outthink the system, and make your way out before time runs out. Do you have what it takes?
Free Transportation will be provided from IFFCO Chowk Metro Station to and from BML Munjal University Campus, Gurugram
Register Now & Secure Your Spot!

title: Altair Data Science Contest
organizer: Dr. Akhilesh Das Gupta Institute of Professional Studies
description:
About:

Challenge: Participants are encouraged to utilize AI Studio from Altair RapidMiner Platform to solve a specific problem, analyze a dataset, or develop a predictive model. Altair RapidMiner platform contains a bunch of tools for Data Analytics and Artificial Intelligence.
Model File: Participants are encouraged to use datasets from Kaggle or a source of choice.
Objective: Develop solutions for data science problems using Altair RapidMiner Platform.

Themes:

Health: Analyze healthcare data to improve patient outcomes, optimize hospital operations, or develop predictive health models.
Education: Utilize data to enhance learning experiences, improve educational outcomes, or develop personalized education plans.
Energy: Investigate energy consumption patterns, optimize resource usage, or develop sustainable energy solutions.
Agriculture: Use data to improve crop yields, manage agricultural resources, or develop innovative farming techniques.
Green Economy: Analyze environmental data to promote sustainability, reduce carbon footprints, or develop green technologies.
Open Innovation: Think of creative and cross-disciplinary approaches to solve any data-related challenge. Think out of the box!

Note:

All themes are marked equally without any bias. They are provided to give some ideas.
This contest is open to all students, except those who have previously won in the Altair Data Science Contest

Key Resources:

Altair Data Science Solutions: Download Software, learn & certify at Altair RapidMiner Academy.
Free Technical Support Forum: Altair Community
Steps to install and activate Altair AI Studio: Steps to install and activate Altair AI Studio
Free student edition license : https://web.altair.com/altair-student-edition
Free educational license : https://web.altair.com/academic-hub-ai-studio

RapidMiner Session .rmp file
Data set used
Analytics PPT
Rapidminer Certificate (max 5 recommended)

Recording of the complete general process (10 to 15 minutes), post on YouTube, and share the link.
If you're using AI Studio, while recording the video, be sure to mention that you are using the AI Studio from Altair RapidMiner Platform.



Submission Instructions:

Zip the contents.
Rename the file as “ECELL_Yourname.zip”.
You also have to submit your zip file here

About Altair RapidMiner:
Altair has over 30 years of experience in data science and data preparation. The Altair RapidMiner platform is a well-established desktop and new-gen SaaS cloud-based platform. It strengthens Altair’s end-to-end data analytics portfolio, offering customers the power to understand, transform, act on, and automate their data. The use of Altair RapidMiner or AI Hub is mandatory for this contest.

Students can download and work on any data set that aligns with their area of interest.

If the data is unstructured, you can make it structured using the Altair Monarch tool.

The contest organizing team can request access to the commercial-grade license of Altair RapidMiner and get it installed in the lab.

title: WebDash - A Website Development Challenge by IEEE JMI
description:
Web Dash is an exciting web development challenge organized by the IEEE Computer Society JMI and IEEE JMI. Participants will be given three themes to choose from, and within 48 hours, they must develop a full-stack website based on their selected theme. The project must be fully functional and deployed by the end of the hackathon, making it a fast-paced and challenging event designed to push participants’ web development skills to the limit
Eligibility:

Open to all undergraduate students.
Solo participation or teams of a maximum of 3 members.
Inter-college teams are allowed.
Inter-specialization teams are allowed.

Competition Format:
Round 1: Website Development Challenge (48 Hours)

Themes will be revealed 1 hour before the competition starts.
Participants must select one theme and build a fully deployed website within 48 hours.
The website should align with the provided theme.

Round 2: Finale at Jamia Millia Islamia

The top 8 teams will be invited to Jamia Millia Islamia on 26th April(tentative) for the final presentation round.

Submission Requirements:

A deployed website link (must be publicly accessible).
A GitHub repository link containing the project code along with a README file explaining the project.
A short video demonstration (maximum 3 minutes) explaining the website’s functionality (Mandatory).

Themes & Problem Statements:

Themes will be revealed 1 hour before the competition begins.

Rules & Regulations:

Participants must choose one theme and develop a website within 48 hours.
No extra time will be given beyond the 48-hour window.
Websites must be fully deployed and accessible via a live link.
No restrictions on technology—participants can use any tech stack.

Judging Criteria:
Projects will be evaluated based on:

Competition Duration: 48 hours

title: LudoHack: Build. Play. Conquer.
description:
Join Discord for further updates: https://discord.com/invite/7MqqbCdgtK
LudoHack is a high-intensity, multi-stage game development hackathon designed to challenge participants in game design, development, and innovation. This competition is structured to test both technical expertise and creative problem-solving through a series of eliminatory rounds, pushing teams to build, iterate, and pitch groundbreaking game concepts.
Competition Format:
LudoHack consists of three progressively challenging rounds, each designed to assess different aspects of game development. All rounds are eliminatory.
Round 1: Game Development & Game Design Quiz

Format: A 15-minute quiz covering core topics in game development, game engines, game physics, rendering, animation, and game design principles.
Team Participation: All team members must complete the quiz, and the team’s average score will be considered for advancement.
Evaluation: Top-performing teams based on the quiz scores will qualify for the next round.

Round 2: 72-Hour Game Development Hackathon

Format: Teams will participate in a 72-hour hackathon where they must develop a complete game based on provided constraints and themes.
Focus Areas:

Gameplay mechanics and responsiveness
Visual and audio quality
Performance optimization
Creativity and innovation


Evaluation: Games will be judged on technical execution, polish, and adherence to the given theme. Only the top teams will proceed to the final round.

Round 3: 24-Hour Creative Game Concept & Pitch

Format: The final round will challenge teams to develop and pitch an entirely new game concept within 24 hours. The goal is to create the most innovative, unique, and marketable game idea.
Tracks: The tracks and themes will be announced prior to the round, ensuring a level playing field for all teams.
Presentation: Teams will present their ideas to a panel of industry experts, game designers, and investors, focusing on:

Originality and uniqueness of the concept
Market potential and scalability
Engagement and user experience


Winning Criteria: The most creative and commercially viable game idea will be declared the winner.

Eligibility and Team Composition:

Open to students, indie developers, and professionals passionate about game development.
Teams must consist of one to three members.
Inter-college and inter-specialization teams are allowed, encouraging diverse collaboration.
Participants must have access to a PC or laptop with Unity, Unreal Engine, or other game development tools.

Registration and Prizes

Cash Prizes, Industry Recognition, and Internship Opportunities for top teams.
Exclusive Mentorship and Networking with industry leaders.

Tracks and additional details will be released closer to the event.
Register now to compete in LudoHack and bring your game ideas to life.
Join Discord for further updates: https://discord.com/invite/7MqqbCdgtK

title: A Jeopardy-Style Capture-The-Flag (CTF)
description:
Capture The Flag (CTF) is an exciting cybersecurity competition where participants compete to uncover ‘flags’, hidden pieces of information concealed within cryptic files, vulnerable programs, or security loopholes. The competition challenges participants in various cybersecurity domains, testing their ability to solve security puzzles and exploit vulnerabilities. Competition FormatThe CTF follows a Jeopardy-style format, where teams solve cybersecurity challenges across multiple categories. The first round will be held online, and only the top-performing teams will qualify for the final round, which will take place offline at CDTI Jaipur .The competition covers various cybersecurity categories, including:

Cryptography
Reverse Engineering
Web Exploitation
Digital Forensics
OSINT (Open-Source Intelligence)
Miscellaneous Cybersecurity Topics

Scoring & Rankings: Each challenge is assigned points based on its difficulty level. More complex challenges yield higher points. Teams will be ranked based on their total score, and in case of a tie, the team that achieves the score in the shortest time will be ranked higher.

Open to unlimited teams
Hosted on VPS with real-time monitoring and technical support
The top 30 teams will qualify for Round 2

Limited to 30 top-performing teams from Round 1
Limited to 30 best-performing teams
Onsite or hybrid setup with live scoreboard and monitoring

title: Code Arena

description:

Each team will receive a printed copy of the problem set.
The questions will be presented in random order and will challenge participants at all skill levels.
Participants must bring their own laptops and strategize based on their strengths.
