title: Machine Learning and Deep Learning Premier League
organizer: Thiagarajar School of Management (TSM), Tamil Nadu
description:
Theme: 
Pan India Datathon: Prediction of IPL Winner Using Past Years' Player and Team Performance Data
Event Overview:
MDPL is an exciting Pan India Datathon that challenges data science enthusiasts to predict the IPL winner by analyzing historical player statistics and team performance data. Participants will leverage machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) techniques to develop predictive models and uncover insights that can forecast this year’s IPL winner.
The event is fully online and conducted on Unstop, encouraging collaboration and technical excellence across disciplines.
Event Details:
Eligibility & Team Composition:

Open to students from all disciplines and degrees.
Inter-college teams are allowed.
Team size: 2-4 members.

Competition Format:

Single Round: Fully online, conducted through Unstop.
Teams should develop predictive models using the given dataset and may supplement their analysis with external data sources to enhance accuracy.

Expected Outcomes:
Model Creation:

Train a machine learning model using historical IPL data to predict the winner, runner-up, second runner-up, and eliminator of the IPL 2025 season.
Engineer relevant features that contribute to the model's accuracy.
Evaluate different machine learning algorithms (e.g., logistic regression, random forest, XGBoost) and select the best-performing model based on accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score.

Model Deployment:

Deploy the trained model so it can predict team rankings when given performance statistics from the 2025 dataset.
Ensure the model is user-friendly and allows seamless data input for predictions.

Steps for Participation:
Data Preprocessing:

Clean the data by handling missing values and ensuring proper formatting.
Normalize or standardize data to improve model performance.
Perform feature selection based on correlation and importance metrics.
Participants are allowed to use additional external datasets, such as weather conditions or venue-specific statistics, to enhance their model’s predictive power.

Feature Engineering:

Create new features using domain knowledge (e.g., win percentage, head-to-head records, team form trends, etc.).

Model Training:

Train and test various machine learning models.
Tune hyperparameters using cross-validation and optimization techniques.

Model Evaluation:

Use classification metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, F1 score, and AUC-ROC.
Compare different models and select the best-performing one.

Model Deployment:

Deploy the model using a web-based interface or an Excel/Python-based tool.
Ensure the system is robust and user-friendly.

Evaluation Criteria:

Accuracy of Predictions (15%) – How well the model predicts the top four teams.
Innovative Feature Engineering (20%) – The quality and impact of new features.
Model Selection and Justification (20%) – The reasoning behind the chosen model.
Model Deployment (20%) – The usability and functionality of the deployed model.
Documentation (25%) – Clarity and completeness of the final report.
Only teams that correctly predict the winner will be considered for evaluation.
Predictions must be data-driven, and any speculative or biased predictions will result in disqualification.
Registration fees collected will be donated to a social cause
The registration amount is non-refundable under any circumstances.
The judges' decisions are final and binding.
No appeals or reconsiderations of results will be entertained.

This datathon is an excellent opportunity to showcase predictive modelling skills, feature engineering expertise, and model deployment abilities. Best of luck to all participants!
File Submission Requirements: 
Each submission should be compiled into a zip file with the following contents:
PPT (Maximum 8 Slides):      

Solution and Approach
Key Findings and Outcomes
Visualizations

Excel File:

Cleaned data
Additional data collected beyond the provided dataset

Model Deployment File:

Design and Implementation Process
Code Used
Results and Inferences

Any additional files which contains analysis can be added to the zip file. Teams can go beyond the provided dataset by collecting additional data from the internet (such as number of catches, fielding statistics, etc.) to improve their model's accuracy.
Submissions received after the deadline will not be accepted under any circumstances.
Any form of plagiarism or unethical behaviour will result in immediate disqualification.
Timeline:

Event Launch Date: 28/03/2024
Submission Deadline: 10/05/2025

Additional Information:

Participants can use any programming language, libraries, or ML/DL frameworks to develop their models.
For any queries, reach out to the event coordinators via Unstop.

title: ShlokaDecode: Decode & Develop
organizer: Netaji Subhas University of Technology (NSUT), Delhi
description:
About the CompetitionShlokaDecode is a unique hackathon that blends ancient Hindi Shlokas with modern web development. Participants will decode the meanings of selected Shlokas and use their interpretations to create a functional website that reflects the essence of those Shlokas.
This event challenges participants to combine linguistic proficiency, analytical thinking, and technical skills in a collaborative setting. Whether you're a developer, designer, or language enthusiast, this is an intellectually stimulating competition for you.
Guidelines & Format:

Competition Type: Offline, Onsite Hackathon
Number of Rounds: 1
Duration: 4 Hours
Team Size: 1-4 members (Inter-college and inter-specialization teams are allowed)
Theme: Decoding Hindi Shlokas and developing a website based on their interpretation
Technology Stack: Open choice (HTML, CSS, JavaScript, React, etc.)

Rules & Regulations:

Team Composition: 2-4 members per team.
Problem Statement: Teams will be provided with specific Hindi Shlokas to analyze. Based on your interpretation, you’ll create a website reflecting the essence of the Shloka(s).
Project Requirements:

Extract and interpret the meaning of the provided Shlokas.
Develop a functional, aesthetically appealing website in 4 hours.
The website’s theme must align with the decoded essence of the Shloka(s).



Judging Criteria:

Interpretation & Understanding (30%) – Depth and accuracy of Shloka interpretation.
Technical Implementation (30%) – Quality of code, website functionality, and execution.
Creativity & Innovation (20%) – Originality of the concept and presentation.
UI/UX Design (20%) – Visual appeal and user experience.

Submission Guidelines:

Deploy your website on a hosting platform (GitHub Pages, Vercel, Netlify, etc.) and submit the link before the deadline.

Disqualification Criteria:

Plagiarism, incomplete submissions, or failure to meet the competition guidelines will result in disqualification.

title: Code Relay
organizer: Indian Institute of Information Technology (IIIT), Surat
description:
Code Relay is a unique programming challenge that puts teamwork and problem-solving skills to the test. In this event, teams of three will collaborate to solve coding problems, but with a twist—each member will have a limited time to write their part of the code before passing it on to the next teammate.Success in this challenge requires not just strong coding skills, but also seamless coordination, strategic thinking, and efficient problem-solving under time constraints. The final output will be evaluated based on correctness and efficiency.
Guidelines

Eligibility:

Open to all college students.
Teams must consist of exactly three members.


Event Format & Process:
Team Structure: Each team consists of three members, working sequentially.
Challenge Structure:

The first teammate starts coding within a given time limit.
After time runs out, they must pass the code to the second teammate, who continues building upon it. Then passes on to the third teammate.
This goes on till the solution is finalized for submission.


Programming Language Requirement: Since teams must submit a single complete solution per problem, all teammates must use the same programming language throughout the challenge.
Evaluation Criteria:
The final solution will be judged based on correctness, efficiency, and teamwork execution.

Why Participate:

Develop coordination and adaptability in a coding environment.
Experience a new, exciting approach to competitive programming.
Challenge yourself and your team to think strategically under pressure.
Win exciting prizes, certificates, and swags!

Are you and your teammates ready to take on the Code Relay Challenge? Register now and put your collaboration skills to the test!

title: AppXcess - AI & Web3 Hacks
description:
About the Competition:
AppXcess - AI & Web3 Hacks is not just another hackathon—it’s a battleground where creativity meets technology! This online hackathon challenges developers, designers, and innovators to think beyond conventional boundaries and build groundbreaking software solutions from scratch.
With complete freedom to choose their problem statements, participants will embark on a journey of innovation, crafting solutions that solve real-world challenges through AI and Web3 Technologies while pushing the limits of their technical expertise. Whether you're a seasoned coder or a rising tech enthusiast, this is your chance to showcase your problem-solving prowess, collaborate with like-minded minds, and compete for incredible prizes.
AppXcess - AI & Web3 Hacks Online Hackathon Guidelines:
Idea Submission Guidelines:
Participants are required to adhere to the following format while submitting their project ideas. Submissions that do not follow the structure may not be considered for evaluation.
Submission Format:

Idea Title: Clearly mentioned on the cover page of the submission.
Problem Statement: A brief and specific description of the problem you aim to solve.
Approach: Explain how your team intends to solve the problem using technology. Highlight your innovative solution.
Solution Overview with Diagram:

Include a mockup or prototype image of your proposed solution.
Represent the business model and/or technical architecture in a visual format (flowchart, diagram, etc.).



Final Project Submission Guidelines
To ensure a fair and effective evaluation process, please follow the detailed guidelines below for your final project submission:

Project AbstractA brief overview (3–4 sentences) describing the objective, functionality, and impact of your project.
GitHub Repository LinkEnsure that your codebase is well-documented and accessible. Include a README file with instructions to run the project.
Project Presentation (PPT or Video)Choose one or both of the following:

PowerPoint Presentation

Maximum of 15 slides
Should include team introduction, problem statement, solution overview, tech stack, user journey, and future scope


Video

Duration: 2 to 5 minutes
Team members should explain the project flow and demonstrate key features




Proof of Concept (PoC) – Working Demo

Provide a functional demonstration of your application or website.
A recorded video showcasing the working product is required.
The demo should reflect core features and problem-solving aspects, even if it's not a fully polished version.



Judging Criteria:
Your project will be evaluated based on the following parameters to ensure fairness and a comprehensive assessment of innovation, execution, and presentation:



Criteria
Points
Description




Innovation & Creativity
25
Judges will assess the originality and uniqueness of the idea. Does the solution introduce a novel approach to the problem? A truly innovative project will stand out.


Technical Implementation
25
The complexity, efficiency, and robustness of the technical execution will be analyzed. Is the architecture scalable and efficient? Is the code clean and well-organized?


Performance & Functionality
20
The project must function seamlessly with minimal bugs. Judges will evaluate if core functionalities are properly implemented and optimized.


User Experience (UI/UX)
20
A great product must also be user-friendly and visually appealing. Is the design intuitive? Does it enhance the overall experience?


Presentation & Feasibility
10
The solution must be well-communicated and practically feasible. Teams should articulate the solution effectively and highlight real-world applicability.



Rules & Disqualification Criteria:
To maintain the integrity and competitiveness of the hackathon, all participants must adhere to the following rules:

This is a fully online hackathon. Teams will submit their projects within the given deadline, and evaluations will be conducted based on the provided materials.
Originality is key. All submissions must be the original work of the participating team. Plagiarized or copied projects will result in immediate disqualification.
Ethical coding practices must be followed. Any form of unethical behavior, such as unauthorized use of external code without proper attribution, will not be tolerated.
Respect the hackathon guidelines. Participants are expected to comply with the given submission requirements, timelines, and presentation formats.
Teamwork and fair play are essential. Any reports of misconduct, sabotage, or disruptive behavior will be investigated and may lead to disqualification.
Judging decisions are final. The evaluation of the judges will be based on the established criteria, and their decision will be binding and non-negotiable.

Rewards:
To encourage innovation and recognize talent, we are offering exciting opportunities for the top-performing teams:

1st Place: ₹1,00,000 + 3-day trip to Malaysia
2nd Place: ₹75,000
3rd Place: ₹50,000
Bonus: Internship opportunities will be provided for the top 3 teams

This is your chance to showcase your technical expertise, creativity, and problem-solving skills in an entirely virtual competition. Push the boundaries of artificial intelligence, collaborate with like-minded innovators, and make your mark at AppXcess - AI & Web3 Hacks.NOTE :  Once your registration is complete, you will receive an email within 2 days with further instructions for submitting your project.

title: Dev Dash
description:
Welcome to Dev Dash, where coding meets speed in an electrifying relay race like never before! This event is designed for teams who can think fast, code faster, and race to victory. Each participant must complete a coding challenge before passing the baton to their next teammate, racing against time and competing with the best.This competition is not just a test of coding skills—it’s a challenge of endurance, problem-solving, and teamwork. If you love coding, enjoy high-energy challenges, and thrive under pressure, Dev Dash is your ultimate test!
Eligibility:

Open to all college students.
Inter-college teams are not allowed. (All team members must be from the same college.)
Inter-specialization teams are allowed. (Students from different branches/departments can form a team.)
A team must consist of exactly 4 members—no solo or incomplete teams allowed.

Event Format:

Stage 1: Sprint + Syntax
Sprint: 50m run to the coding station.
Task: Solve basic syntax errors or write a quick function (e.g., sorting an array, calculating Fibonacci).
Tests basic programming skills and logical thinking.  
Stage 2: Debug Dash
Dash: 30m run to the next station.
Task: Debug a pre-written piece of code with 3-5 hidden errors (logical or syntactical).
Errors could include infinite loops, incorrect variable usage, or logic flaws.
Stage 3: Caesar Cipher
Sprint: 30m run to the encryption challenge.
Task: Implement or decrypt a Caesar Cipher, a classic encryption technique where each letter is shifted by a fixed number of positions in the alphabet.
Tests encryption, string manipulation, and problem-solving skills.
Stage 4: Tables Have Turned
Sprint: 30m dash to the final coding station.
Task: Given a correct piece of code, intentionally modify it to produce incorrect outputs.
Final Challenge: Participants must explain their changes to a judge within 1 minute.
Tests reverse debugging, critical thinking, and the ability to understand existing code.

Total Event Duration:

Round 1 (Qualifier Sprint): 30 minutes
Break & Preparation: 10 minutes
Round 2 (Final Relay Race): 2 hours 30 minutes

Rules & Guidelines:

Each team must have 4 members. No individual or incomplete registrations will be accepted.
Every participant must complete a coding challenge before running. Skipping the challenge results in immediate disqualification.
Coding problems will vary in difficulty (ranging from logic-based puzzles to debugging challenges).
Participants must complete both the coding and physical tasks at their station before passing the baton. Penalty time will be added for incomplete tasks or skipped obstacles.
Code must pass automated validation to proceed. Unlimited attempts are allowed, but debugging must be done individually, without teammate assistance.
No external help or devices are allowed. Any form of cheating will result in team disqualification.
The baton must be physically handed over to the next participant before they start their challenge.
The winning team will be decided based on time and accuracy. Faster completion gives an edge, but incorrect solutions will lead to penalties.
The decision of the event organizers is final and binding.

Why Join Dev Dash?

Unique Coding Experience: Unlike traditional coding competitions, Dev Dash adds a physical challenge, making it a true test of endurance and quick thinking.
Enhance Your Problem-Solving Skills: Every second counts! Solve coding challenges under time constraints and sharpen your logic and debugging skills.
Teamwork & Strategy: Work together, plan efficiently, and optimize your coding speed to outpace the competition.
Exciting Prizes & Recognition: Compete for exclusive rewards and earn bragging rights as the fastest coding team on campus!

Free Transportation will be provided from IFFCO Chowk Metro Station to and from BML Munjal University Campus, Gurugram
Ready to Code, Run & Win?
Think you and your team have what it takes to be the fastest coders on the track? Sign up now and put your skills to the ultimate test!

title: Kriyeta 4.0
description:
All That You Need to Know About Kriyeta 4.0 (National Level Hackathon) : Sponsored by IEEE Humanitarian Technologies and eInfochips 
About:
Kriyeta 4.0 is a nationwide stage that instills a culture of innovation and motivates youth to develop a problem-solving mindset in a competitive energy environment that facilitates rapid development. Create, innovate, learn, and discover in a time-constrained coding event that gives the nation's brightest minds a chance to showcase their skills and try their hand at solving problems often faced by the masses.
Other Details:
Date: April 18th - 20th, 2025 (48-Hour Hackathon)Location: Acropolis Institute of Technology and Research - AITR, IndorePlatform: As this is a coding opportunity, you can use any platform for coding on your laptop within the premises, such as VSCode, Sublime, GitHub, etc.
Domains : 

Sustainable Technologies
Healthcare Innovation
AI and Emerging Technologies
Agriculture and Food Security

Problem Statement:

Domain: Sustainable Technologies: Agentic AI Assistant for Sustainable Urban Mobility Planning

Problem Statement: Design an Agentic AI solution that helps city planners or citizens plan eco-friendly travel using real-world constraints like public transport availability, distance, cost, and CO2 emissions. Agents can compare options (e.g., bike vs cab), optimize based on user goals (fastest vs greenest), and simulate outcomes.
Expected Outcome: A travel planner tool: user inputs start/end → agents compare routes, emissions, cost, and recommend best green option


Smart AI Assistant for Home Energy Optimization

Problem Statement: Build a smart assistant that takes simulated home energy consumption data (CSV/mock API) and uses AI to analyze usage patterns, detect wastage, and recommend personalized optimization strategies. It should generate a daily or weekly tip in natural language using LLMs.
Expected Outcome: AI-based dashboard + recommendation engine + mock data pipeline


Domain : Healthcare Innovation: Agentic AI Framework for Hospital Workflow Automation

Problem Statement: Design a multi-agent AI system using Microsoft AutoGen to simulate an Agentic AI workforce for hospital workflows such as appointment scheduling, EMR data retrieval, and billing validation. Agents should be autonomous, communicate with each other, and collectively complete a task.
Expected Outcome: End-to-end working demo with 2–3 agents automating tasks like patient appointment + EMR fetch + billing info.


Agentic AI-Based Personalized Health Coach for Preventive Care

Problem Statement: Design an Agentic AI system using Microsoft AutoGen to simulate a personalized health coach that helps users reduce risks of chronic conditions (e.g., diabetes, hypertension). The AI agents should work together to assess user risk, recommend personalized lifestyle changes, and provide motivational feedback over time.
Expected Outcome: A multi-agent health advisory platform: profile intake → risk analysis → AI-generated recommendations + follow-up agent.


Domain : AI and Emerging Technologies: Multi-Agent Communication Framework

Problem Statement: Design a reusable framework using Microsoft AutoGen to simulate collaboration between multiple AI agents (e.g., planner, summarizer, validator) to solve complex tasks. The framework should be modular, allowing users to plug in new agent types and control the task flow via config.
Expected Outcome: A modular agent collaboration framework with 2-3 sample task flows (e.g., text summarization, Q&A pipeline)


Agentic AI Framework for Smart Email Triage and Action Automation

Problem Statement: Create a reusable platform using Agentic AI where agents collaboratively classify incoming emails (mock or real), extract action items, assign them to categories (e.g., meetings, follow-ups, approvals), and generate suggested responses or summaries. Useful for overloaded professionals and internal use.
Expected Outcome: An end-to-end email triage assistant that tags, summarizes, and drafts replies via interacting agents


Domain : Agriculture and Food Security: AI- Powered Pest Control System

Problem Statement: Develop an AI-driven pest detection system that analyzes real-time images from drones or mobile devices to identify harmful pests. The system should provide early warnings and suggest eco-friendly solutions to mitigate pest attacks.
Expected Outcome: Enhances pest detection, minimizes crop loss, and promotes eco-friendly pest management.


Food Waste Management and Redistribution Platform

Problem Statement: Build a tech-enabled food waste management system that connects farmers, retailers, and NGOs to track, reduce, and redistribute surplus food to people in need. The system should include AI-powered demand forecasting to prevent food wastage.



Objective: Reduces food wastage, optimizes redistribution, and contributes to hunger alleviation.
Rules:

Participants must bring their own systems for the hackathon. The organizing team will only provide internet connectivity. It is the responsibility of each team to ensure they have the necessary hardware and software tools to participate effectively.
Each team should choose a designated colour to represent their identity. All team members are required to wear the chosen colour during the event for easy identification.
Throughout the entire duration of the event, a minimum of 50 per cent of the team members must be present at the designated arena. Failure to meet this requirement may result in disqualification
If the team fails to qualify for the first round no refund will be provided.
Each team must consist of 3 to 5 members with a compulsion of 1 female member, ensuring a collaborative environment. 
Participants are required to remain on the premises for the entire duration of the 48-hour hackathon. Leaving the premises during the event is strictly prohibited.
Any participant found engaging in unethical practices, including but not limited to cheating, plagiarism, or unauthorized use of resources, will lead to disqualification of the entire team. Upholding integrity and ethical conduct is paramount in maintaining a fair and competitive environment.
No separate rooms will be provided to teams, a common lodging facility will be there.
To & Fro conveyance to the institute has to be born by the team.
Team Introduction, Problem Statement, Proposed Solution, Benefit to Society, Future Scope, Reference (this should be the content of the ppt and only proposed solution can go to maximum 3 slides rest 1 slide each)
No refund of registration fees will be provide if the teams are disqualified after Round 1 i.e PPT Submission

Note: These rules and regulations are in place to ensure a fair, inclusive, and professional hackathon experience for all participants. Violation of any of these rules may result in penalties or disqualification, as determined by the organizing committee.

title: Capture The Flag
description:
The Capture The Flag (CTF) Competition is an intense cybersecurity challenge designed to test participants' skills in ethical hacking, cryptography, digital forensics, and problem-solving. The competition follows a Jeopardy-style format, where teams solve security-based challenges across multiple domains. Each challenge contains a hidden "flag" (secret code) that must be discovered and submitted to earn points.
Participants will engage in tasks such as decrypting encoded messages, analyzing malware, identifying vulnerabilities in web applications, and investigating forensic evidence. The event is structured to accommodate both beginners and experienced cybersecurity enthusiasts, with challenges ranging from basic to advanced difficulty levels. The team accumulating the highest score by the end of the competition will be declared the winner.
Mode: Offline
Event Overview:

Date & Time: April 20th, 2025 | 10:30 AM
Location: BML Munjal University, Gurugram

Guidelines:

Eligibility: The competition is open to all students interested in cybersecurity, ethical hacking, and digital forensics.
 Prior experience in cybersecurity is helpful but not mandatory.
Inter-College Participation: Students from different colleges are allowed to form teams and compete together.
Format: The event follows a Jeopardy-style Capture The Flag (CTF) format.
Teams will solve cybersecurity-related challenges across multiple domains.
Each challenge contains a hidden "flag" (a secret code) to be found and submitted.

Number of Challenges: 
The event will consist of challenges covering:

Cryptography (breaking encryption techniques)
Web security (finding vulnerabilities in websites)
Reverse engineering (analyzing software)
Digital forensics (extracting data from files)
Binary exploitation (finding security flaws in executables)

Duration:

The competition will run for a fixed time.
Teams must solve as many challenges as possible within the time limit.

Scoring System:

Points will be awarded based on challenge difficulty.
More complex challenges yield higher scores.
The team with the highest score wins.
In case of a tie, the team that completed the final challenge in the shortest time wins.

Rules:

No Unauthorized Access: Participants must not attempt to hack or access other teams’ accounts, event platforms, or any external systems.
No Denial-of-Service (DoS) Attacks: Any team attempting to conduct a DoS attack or disrupt other teams will be disqualified.
No External Help: Teams must work independently without unauthorized external resources or non-participant assistance.
No Sharing of Solutions: Teams must not share or exchange challenge solutions or flags during the event.
No Cheating: Any form of cheating, including exploiting bugs in the event platform or challenges, will result in immediate disqualification.
Allowed Tools: Participants may use open-source or freely available tools to solve challenges (e.g., Burp Suite, SQLMap, Wireshark, Ghidra).
Online Resources: Participants can use search engines for guidance but must not post questions on public forums during the event.
Flag Format and Validation: The correct flag format must be followed to score points (e.g., FLAG{example}).
Submissions not matching the expected flag format will not be scored.
Disqualification: The event organizers have the final say in disqualifying teams that break the rules.
Final Result: At the end of the event, the team with the highest score will be declared the winner. In case of a tie, the team that solved the most difficult challenge first will win.

Free Transportation will be provided from IFFCO Chowk Metro Station to and from BML Munjal University Campus, Gurugram

title: International Quant Championship 2025
description:
About WorldQuant and WorldQuant BRAIN:Headquartered in the US, WorldQuant is a quantitative asset management firm founded in 2007 with over 1000 employees spread across 27 global offices. We seek to produce high-quality predictive signals (alphas) through our proprietary research platform. These signals are employed in financial strategies across a variety of asset classes and global markets.WorldQuant BRAIN Research Consultant ProgramJoin our global community of 5,000+ research consultants



Flexible approach to work — Have the freedom to work when and how you want from eligible regions across the globe.
Exclusive events and offers — Opportunity to join competitions and meetups organized exclusively for BRAIN Research Consultants
Merit-based compensation — Have the opportunity to be compensated based on the quality of your ideas.
Data and exclusive features — Access 150,000 + data fields and advanced features to build Alphas
Quant advisory program — Cohort-based learning guided by an experienced quant researcher and hands-on support.

IQC: A Global Quantitative Finance Modeling Competition
Ready. Set. Quant!
Break into the world of quantitative finance and sign up for WorldQuant BRAIN's International Quant Championship - a Global Quantitative Finance Modeling Competition.
Key Details:

 IQC is a global, three-stage, team-based quantitative finance competition. 
Participants start by forming teams of 1-4 teammates from the same university and compete across the various stages by developing and backtesting Alphas * on BRAIN, WorldQuant’s Simulation platform
If the team scores well, its members will have the opportunity to compete in the designated finals for their respective country, territory, or region — and potentially in the global championship, which is expected to be held in person in Singapore in September**
 Top-scoring teams may be eligible to win cash prizes from a pool of up to US$100,000, subject to eligibility**
 WorldQuant is always on the lookout for talent, and certain eligible participants who score well in the IQC may be considered for research consulting, internship, or full-time employment opportunities.  

 *Alphas are mathematical models that seek to predict the future price movements of various financial instruments.
**Please refer to the official guidelines for all rules and restrictions
Eligibility*:

Anybody above the age of 18 can apply
Certain individuals (e.g., WorldQuant employees, past winners, BRAIN Research Consultants) cannot participate. 

*Please refer to the official guidelines for all rules and restrictions.
How to Participate:

Step 1: You must register on the Unstop platform to access the competition URL.Note: Individual team members can register on Unstop and WorldQuant BRAIN. Teams can be formed directly on the BRAIN platform
Step 2: Sign up - Sign up or sign into your account on our WorldQuant BRAIN platform: Create a BRAIN account. This step has to be done individually by each team member.
Step 3: Team up - Form a team of 1-4 members from your university. You can invite other IQC registrants to join your team on the BRAIN platform.
Step 4: Learn - Access our free learning videos and documentation about quant finance research and modelling.
Step 5: Compete - Increase your score by submitting Alphas* on BRAIN using historical financial market data and predefined operators.

*Alphas are mathematical models that seek to predict the future price movements of various financial instruments.”
Rewards & Prizes*:

Cash prizes from a pool of US$100,000

Stage 2 (National/Regional) Winners (Total $6,000 in each Finals):

1st place: $3,000
2nd place: $2,000
3rd place: $1,000


Stage 3 (Global Finals) Winners (Total $40,000):

1st place: $20,000
2nd place: $12,000
3rd place: $8,000




Prizes are divided equally among team members in USD currency
Potential Research Consultant Opportunities, Internships and Full-Time Roles
Top performers may also be invited to compete in the global finals expected to be held in Singapore in September 2025
Learn more about quantitative finance, and expand your educational and career objectives

*Please refer to the official guidelines for all rules and restrictions
Free Research Webinars:
During IQC, learn more about quantitative finance, and expand your educational and career objectives, through our Free Research Webinars:

Register here: Link 
Every Thursday, from 20 March – 6:30 pm IST
Topic covered:

Introduction to WorldQuant BRAIN and the International Quant Championship 2025
Fundamental and Model Datasets
Price Volume Data
Tips to build submittable quant models

title: Code X Celerate 2K25
description:
Submission Rules for CodeXecelerate 2K25
Thank you for your interest in participating in CodeXecelerate 2K25 Please carefully follow these submission guidelines based on the type of solution you are proposing. Failure to comply with these rules may result in disqualification.
Hardware Solution: 
1.Video Submission:Submit a video that demonstrates the overall functionality of your solution. Ensure all components are clearly explained.Highlight the usage of your product and elaborate on your business motto.
2. PPT Submission:Prepare and submit your presentation PPT format 
Software Solution (Web App, Mobile App, and others):
1.Drive Link Submission:Put all the files and folders related to your project into a shared drive folder.Ensure the drive link is accessible and submit it for evaluation.Your submission will be checked for both the code quality and functionality.
2.Hosting Encouragement:
Hosting your project significantly increases your chances of winning.Submit the link to your hosted application for evaluation.
3.PPT Submission:
Prepare and submit your presentation in the prescribed PPT format provided by the organizers.
Online Coding Challenge: CodeXcelerate
Hackathon Tracks:


Mobile App Development


Web Development


Data Science & Machine Learning


Blockchain & Cryptography


Open Innovation


Guidelines & Eligibility:
Who Can Participate?


Open to students, developers, and tech enthusiasts from all backgrounds.


Inter-college and inter-specialization teams are welcome.


Team Formation


Teams must have 3 to 5 members.


Each team must include at least one female member to promote diversity and inclusivity.


Collaboration and diversity in skill sets are encouraged.


Format & Duration


CodeXcelerate is a completely online 24-hour hackathon where participants develop innovative solutions.


No predefined problem statements will be provided—teams must come up with their own real-world challenges to solve.

Clarity of the idea
Feasibility and innovation

Join Whatsapp group for more updates : Click Here To Join

Remote Patient Monitoring Using IoT: Track patient vitals in real-time.
Secure Health Records Using Blockchain: Safeguard medical records with encryption.
Open Innovation: Any innovative solution related to healthcare challenges.

Smart Pest Detection with AI: Identify and mitigate pests in crops.
IoT-Based Crop Disease Monitoring: Detect and alert for crop diseases.
Blockchain-Based Supply Chain for Farmers: Ensure transparency in the supply chain.

3. Education

AI-Powered Virtual Tutor: Provide personalized learning assistance.
Blockchain-Based Certificate Verification: Verify certificates securely.

Open Innovation: Solutions that revolutionize the education sector.

Finance/FinTech

AI-Based Fraud Detection: Identify fraudulent transactions in real time.
Decentralized Payment Gateway: Secure transactions using blockchain.
Budget Management with AI Insights: Offer personalized financial advice.

Smart City & IoT

Smart Waste Management System: Optimize waste collection using IoT.

Bonus Points: Teams developing AI Agents to improve solution efficiency and automate tasks will receive additional credits, making their project stand out.
 
Hackathon RulesTeam Formation:

Teams must consist of 3 to 4 members.
All team members should be from the same institute.
Inter-specialization teams within the same college are allowed.

General Guidelines:

Plagiarism is strictly prohibited. Any copied or pre-built solution/projects will lead to immediate disqualification.
Participants should bring their own laptops and necessary peripherals.
Usage of third-party APIs and libraries is allowed, provided they are properly cited.

Submission Rules:

All projects must be submitted before the deadline to qualify for evaluation.
Each team will have to present their project during the final round.

title: CSAY India Hackathon 2025
description:
CSAY India Hackathon 2025 – A Key Initiative Under CSAY 1.0
CSAY India Hackathon 2025 is an integral part of Cyber & Social Awareness Yatra 1.0 (CSAY 1.0), India’s largest cyber awareness initiative.The finalists will be invited to CDTI (Bureau of Police Research and Development) Jaipur for an offline presentation before an expert jury panel. Winners will be announced on the same day after jury deliberation.
Problem Statements:

API Guardian: API Security
AppClone Buster: Clone and Fake App Mitigation
NeuralShield: AI for Threat Detection & Incident Response
DarkWeb Watchdog: Monitoring & Analyzing Dark Web Activities
PhishNet: Detecting and Preventing Phishing Attacks
Open Innovation: User-Submitted Solutions

The Open Innovation category allows participants to submit any technology-related idea that addresses cybersecurity, smart policing, cyber awareness, smart cities, AgriTech, FinTech, or other emerging tech-driven challenges.
This category encourages out-of-the-box thinking, novel approaches, and disruptive innovations that may not fit into predefined problem statements but have the potential for real-world impact. Participants can leverage AI, blockchain, IoT, cloud security, data privacy, automation, or any other technology to propose solutions that enhance security, efficiency, and digital resilience.
Organizer & Partner

Organized by: Singhtek
Knowledge Partner: Central Detective Training Institute (CDTI ), BPRD Jaipur

title: Planet Hunt

description:

Eligibility Criteria:

All students from authorized institutions and colleges are eligible to participate.
Team size limit is a maximum of three members.

title: Code Debugging
organizer: Indian Institute of Information Technology (IIIT), Surat
description:
The Code Debugging Challenge is a thrilling coding competition designed to test participants' ability to identify and fix errors in buggy programs within the shortest possible time. It’s a race against time where precision, logical thinking, and debugging skills will determine the winners.The competition will be conducted in multiple rounds, with each round featuring progressively challenging bugs. Only the best problem-solvers will advance through the rounds and emerge victorious.
Guidelines

Eligibility:

Open to all college students.
Participants can compete individually.


Event Format & Process:

Multiple Rounds: The competition consists of 2 rounds with increasing levels of difficulty.
Challenge Structure: Participants will be provided with buggy programs in the coding language they choose and must identify and fix the errors as quickly as possible.


Evaluation Criteria: Accuracy of fixes and speed of debugging.
Why Participate:

Enhance your debugging and problem-solving skills.
Compete against fellow coders in a fast-paced challenge.
Win exciting prizes, certificates, and swags!
Think you have what it takes to debug your way to victory?



Register now and take on the challenge!

title: The Labyrinth
description:
Event Description:

Put your robotics skills to the test! Build and program your Line Follower Robot (LFR) to autonomously follow a track, navigate sharp turns, and race against time. Do you have what it takes to win?
An autonomous robot must navigate through a complex maze and reach the finish line in the shortest time.

title: CodHer'25
description:
CODHER is a national-level inter-college hackathon designed exclusively for women. The main aim of CODHER is to encourage greater participation of women in technical competitions.
Now in its 11th edition, CODHER continues this mission by providing participants with a platform to ideate, collaborate, and demonstrate their technical expertise. Join in and get the chance to tackle real-world challenges using your coding prowess.
General Guidelines:

The registration fee is for the entire team and not for a single participant. 
CodHer’25 is exclusively for female students who are currently in college.
Each team must consist of a minimum of one (1) and a maximum of three (3) students. 
Students are allowed to form teams with members from different colleges.
There are no specific problem statements. Participants can create and solve their own problem statement based on the guidelines given in the subsequent section.
Participants should refer to the round-wise details for further information regarding each phase of the hackathon.
All participants must have Microsoft Teams installed and set up before the hackathon begins (Microsoft Teams is needed for the inaugural ceremony only, subsequent reviews and judging will happen on GMeet).
Inauguration will be held on April 5th, from 9:00 AM to 9:50 AM. Important information will be shared during this session and queries addressed.

Problem Statements & Tracks

Participants may choose any problem statement of their choice, but it must align with at least one of the tracks given below.
A problem statement may fall under multiple tracks, but ONLY one track must be the primary focus. This will be verified by the mentors and judges during reviews.

Available Tracks: 

Gaming for a Cause
Supply Chain & Logistics 
Automation 
GenAI for Security (OR) GenAI in Entertainment
Big Data Analytics 

Mentorship & Reviews:

Each team will be assigned a mentor who will provide guidance and feedback throughout the hackathon.
The first and second review rounds will be conducted by the assigned mentors. Participants are encouraged to use these sessions to seek clarification and receive suggestions for improvement.
All review and judging sessions will take place on Google Meet (meeting links will be shared via WhatsApp).

Judging & Final Presentation:

During the final review and subsequent judging round, participants must either present a live demo or showcase a recorded video of their project.
Along with the demo, participants are expected to submit their presentation (format described in the ‘Submission Guidelines’ section). 

Submission Guidelines:

For all presentations, the format to be followed for the PPT is as follows (Maximum 7 slides):

Problem Statement
Flow/Architecture Diagram
Solution Overview
Tech Stack
Implementation Details


For any queries, please contact the organizing team (details provided in the contact section).

title: Squash The Bug
description:
Get ready for an intense debugging challenge where your problem-solving skills will be put to the test! In this competition, you'll be given faulty code snippets, and your task is to analyze, identify, and fix the bugs within the given time. Accuracy, efficiency, and speed will determine who emerges as the ultimate Bug Squasher!
Guidelines:

Participation is limited to college students (UG/PG).
Team Size: Solo participation 
The event will consist of 2 rounds.

Round 1 - 30 MCQs in 20 min. The top 10(tentative) scorers will proceed to the next round.
Round 2 - 30-minute debugging round.



Winners will be selected based on the number of errors debugged and on the time constraints.
Decisions made by the event organizers will be final and binding. 

Rules:

No External Help

Participants must work alone—no discussion or collaboration with others.


No Personal Electronic Devices

Laptops, mobile phones, smartwatches, or any other electronic devices are not allowed.
Any participant found using an unauthorized device will be immediately disqualified.


Use Only Provided Resources

Participants must only use the computers and materials provided by the organizers.


No Copy-Pasting from External Sources

Any attempt to submit pre-written solutions will lead to disqualification.


Strict Time Limit

Participants must submit their final solutions within the given time.
Late submissions will not be considered.


Behavior & Fair Play

Any form of cheating, misbehavior, or disruption will result in immediate disqualification.



 Venue: Department of Computer Science, University of Delhi
 Date & Time: April 20, 2025 | 3:30 PM
 Duration: 1 Hour 30 Minutes

title: Bit by Bit
description:
Are you ready to decode, decipher, and dominate in an electrifying treasure hunt powered by binary puzzles and mind-bending clues?
Bit by Bit is not just a treasure hunt—it’s a battle of wits, logic, and speed. Each location on campus hides a binary code—your key to unlocking the next challenge. Solve thrilling riddles, crack mysterious clues, and race against time to reach the final destination before anyone else.
What to Expect?

Brain-teasing binary puzzles at every checkpoint
Cryptic clues leading you through a thrilling campus-wide adventure
A test of logic, speed, and strategy—only the sharpest minds will prevail
Exciting prizes for the fastest and most skilled codebreakers

Gather your squad, put on your hacker hat, and embark on the most exhilarating binary treasure hunt of the season. Can you outthink, outpace, and outdecode your competitors?
Event Details:

Date & Time: 19th April 2025, 7:00 PM - 9:00 PM
Team Size: Maximum 5 people per team
Prizes: Await the sharpest minds

Register now and crack the code to victory.
Guidelines & Event Flow:
Team Formation:

Participants can register individually or in teams (maximum of 5 members).
Collaboration is key, but teams must work independently—no external assistance allowed.
Each team must nominate a leader who will be responsible for submitting answers.

Event Format:

The hunt begins with an initial clue provided at the starting point.
Binary-coded hints will be strategically placed across campus locations.
Teams must decode each puzzle to uncover the next mystery location.
The final clue will lead to the ultimate destination—only the fastest team wins.

Puzzle Types
Clues will challenge your binary and logical reasoning skills, including:

Converting binary to text
Performing logical operations 
Solving algorithm-based riddles
Understanding basic cryptography

Time Limit & Scoring:

The event will be time-bound—teams must solve all clues within the duration.
If no team reaches the final destination within the given time, the team with the most solved clues wins.
In case of a tie, the team that reached the farthest checkpoint first will be the winner.

Winning Criteria & Prizes:

The top 3 teams to decode all clues and reach the final destination win.
Prizes and certificates will be awarded to the top-performing teams.
Expect bonus rewards for creativity and teamwork.

Important Notes:

Organizers’ decisions are final in case of disputes.
Respect campus property and follow event coordinators’ instructions.

Rules:

No external help allowed—teams must rely only on their skills.
One wrong clue = Disqualification—accuracy is key.
No interfering with other teams—any misconduct will lead to disqualification.

Free Transportation will be provided from IFFCO Chowk Metro Station to and from BML Munjal University Campus, Gurugram
Get ready to test your binary mastery in the most thrilling treasure hunt of the year. Will your team emerge victorious? Join us and find out.

title: CSS Battlefield
organizer: Indian Institute of Information Technology, Design and Manufacturing (IIITDM), Jabalpur
description:
CSS Battlefield is a fast paced design and coding competition where participants showcase their CSS skills by replicating given designs with pixel-perfect precision. Participants will be tasked with replicating 3 still images and 2 animated GIFs using pure CSS. Speed, creativity, and attention to detail will be the keys to victory.
Rules and Guidelines:

Prohibited Practices:

Copy-pasting code from external sources or templates.
Using online tools like Figma-to-Code converters.
Late submissions (strict time limits will be enforced).
JavaScript and frameworks are not allowed; only HTML and CSS.


Disqualification:

Plagiarism or unethical behavior will result in immediate disqualification.


General:

All final decisions lie in the hands of the judges.
If a participant takes part in two or more events, it is their responsibility to manage their participation.



Eligibility Criteria:
Open to all IIITDMJ students and external participants.
Evaluation Criteria- With Judging process:

Pixel Perfection: How closely the design matches the given reference. - AutomatedCode Size: Lower the total number of characters, higher the points. - AutomatedTime of Submission: Faster submissions will be ranked above in case of tie. - AutomatedAnimation Timing: Animations and related properties ensuring smooth looping. - Manual’

Event Format:

Participation:

Participants can compete individually or in teams of two.


Challenges:

Each team will receive 3 screenshots (still images) and 2 animated GIFs to replicate using pure CSS.
Each challenge will have a different point value based on its difficulty level.


Time Limit:

Teams will have a maximum of 150 minutes to submit all their code.
Teams can submit and lock each problem as soon as they solve it.


Tiebreaker:

In case of a tie in points, the team that submits their solutions earlier will be preferred.
If the tie persists, the team with the lowest accumulated time for all submissions will rank higher.


Tools:

The use of AI tools, including GitHub Copilot, is strictly prohibited.
The implementation must be in pure CSS, and external CSS libraries (e.g., Bootstrap, Tailwind) are not allowed.


Judges:

The judging panel will consist of experienced mentors and designers from TPC. Their decision will be final and binding.
Pixel Perfection and code length will be judged by automated scripts.



Why Participate:

Enhance CSS Skills – Master flexbox, grid, animations, and pixel-perfect precision.
Boost Problem-Solving – Learn to tackle complex layouts using pure CSS.
Competitive Edge – Improve coding speed and attention to detail under time constraints.
Showcase Creativity – Experiment with unique design techniques and animations.
Recognition & Networking – Gain visibility in the CSS community and connect with fellow developers.
Portfolio & Resume Boost – Stand out to recruiters with real-world CSS challenges.

Accomodation :

title: Innovation Challenge: Atlas Copco
organizer: Birla Institute of Technology & Science, Pilani Campus
description:
Challenge Objectives:

Implicit Knowledge Capturing:

Develop methods to harvest tacit insights from expert interactions.
Utilize AI agents capable of initiating calls or chats to extract subject matter intelligence autonomously.


Knowledge Gap Identification:

Identify areas where Knowledge Management Systems face gaps.
Recognize missing or underrepresented critical information.
Integrate explicit data with implicit insights to create a comprehensive knowledge map.


Efficient Retrieval:

Design a system that ensures rapid, computationally efficient access to stored information.
Enable the system to handle a high volume of data from multiple sources.


Integration of Explicit & Implicit Knowledge:

Seamlessly combine structured data (documents, records) with unstructured data (conversations, expert insights).
Provide enriched insights reflecting both factual and experiential knowledge.


User-Friendly Platform:

Develop an intuitive interface for easy design, integration, and navigation.
Focus on accessibility to encourage adoption across various teams.


Defined Entity Relationships:

Map relationships between different data entities such as individuals, teams, and documents.
Maintain clear links among people, data, and organizational units to enhance system utility.


Actionable Insights Conversion:

Enable the system to translate retrieved information into actionable recommendations.
Tailor outputs to domain-specific challenges (e.g., CAD design for Mechanical teams, custom software solutions for Apps & Software teams, etc.).



Deliverables:

A working prototype demonstrating:

Efficient data storage, indexing, and retrieval of both explicit and implicit knowledge.
Integration of various data formats and conversion of raw data into actionable insights.


A detailed technical overview including:

Potential architectures and design strategies.
Knowledge mapping techniques tailored to Mechanical, Embedded Systems, Apps & Software, Electrical, and Data & Analytics domains.












References:

a) AI agent for knowledge management: Key capabilities, use cases, benefits and implementation
b) AI in Knowledge Management: Benefits, Concerns and Future
c) The Ultimate Guide to Knowledge Management: Strategies, Tools, and Best Practices | Creately
d) The power of AI in knowledge management: Transforming organizations with data-driven insights | by LeewayHertz | Nerd For Tech | Medium
e) Unleashing the Future of Knowledge Management with Agentic AI
f) How a Knowledge Management System Can Help Customer Service

title: Line Follower Robot
organizer: Cluster Innovation Centre (DUCIC), University of Delhi (DU), Delhi
description:
Welcome to the Line Follower Robot competition! Through your innovative mindset build a robotic masterpiece bot capable of autonomously navigating a designated course by precisely following a visible line. Display your knowledge in sensor integration, algorithm design, and control systems. Glorify your bot by demonstrating its speed, accuracy, and adaptability through artificial intelligence and engineering power.
Objective:

Team to build own autonomous robot within the specified dimensions to achieve the maximum speed on the given track and reach the destination in minimum time. The robot must start behind the starting point and is considered to have crossed the finishing line if any part of the robot crosses it in a full lap of the course. The robot must follow the black line. The competition area has a special place defined for the robot’s operation (hereafter Competition Field).

Arena:

The game field consists of an arena having dimensions 275cm X 275cm (L x B). It consists of the following:
The arena has a path of a black strip, of width 3 cm, on a background of white color.
The figure below shows the sample arena. The actual arena at the competition will consist of alterations in the path.
The path will consist of a singular continuous, non-intersecting line

Note: The dimensions of the arena will be accurate to within 5% or 20 mm, whichever is less, the color of the arena will be according to the instructions specified in the arena details.
Gameplay:

A match is played by a single team in one go, with each team consisting of 1 Wireless Bot.
An individual may participate or construct a team of a minimum of 1 and a maximum of 5 members.
Any institution (School/College/University/Vocational Institution) or group of students (within defined age), may form a team.
Each team will be given three tries out of which the best one will be considered.

Bot Specifications:
The participating bots must be wireless and autonomous. It can be circular / Rectangular in style. The bot must fit inside a box 20 centimeters in length, 20 centimeters wide, and 20 centimeters in height at any point in time. Maximum weight should not be more than 5Kgs including battery, however, a tolerance of 5% in weight is acceptable. Participants need to ensure:

Batteries must be sealed, immobilized electrolyte type (gel cell, lithium, NiCad, or dry cells).
The electric voltage anywhere in the machine should not be more than 16.8V DC at any point in time for each robot.
Infrared light-reflecting materials must not be used on the outside. If robots are painted, they must be painted matte. Minor parts that reflect infrared light could be used only if other robots are unaffected. Robots must not produce magnetic interference for other robots on the field.
If a team claims that their robot is affected by the other team’s robot in any way they must show proof/evidence of the interference. A Referee must confirm any interference if a claim is placed by the other team.
The robot must be autonomous.
Robots must be constructed and programmed in a way that their movement is not limited to only one direction and must move in all directions.
No wireless communication between the bot and the operator will be allowed.
Bluetooth, RF Module, etc not allowed on the bot.
Any robotic parts/building material can be used until the robot meets the above specifications and if the design and construction are primarily the original work of the team ready-made robots are not allowed to compete in the competition.

Game Rules:

Teams will be given 1 minute for calibration. If any team is found to be making any changes in the software or the hardware after depositing its bots (apart from minor hardware adjustments), then it will be immediately disqualified from the competition.
Only one autonomous bot per team is allowed.
When the bot starts, no team member is allowed to touch the bot or enter the arena.
At the start of the task, the bot will be placed at the starting point. Only 1 team member is allowed to be near the game field while starting the bot.
The run will start only when the organizers give the signal.
The starting procedure of the bot should be simple and should not involve giving the bot any manual force or impulse in any direction.


A total of 5 minutes will be given for each run. The bot has to finish the dry run and main run in that period only.

Restarts:

The participants are allowed to take a maximum of 3 restarts in the entire match. If the bot takes a restart, it has to start from the start zone of the arena.
The timer will be set back to zero in case of a restart.
During a restart, a contestant must not feed information about the arena to the bot.
However, contestants are allowed to adjust sensors (gain, position, etc.) and make hardware changes.
The contestant must not alter the bot in any manner that reduces its weight (e.g. removal of a bulky sensor array or switching to lighter batteries to get better speed). The organizers reserve the right to arbitrate in such circumstances.

General Rules:

Only 1 member of the team is allowed to handle the bot.
Participants are not allowed to keep anything inside the arena other than the bot.
Laptops/personal computers are not allowed near the arena. Other Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, etc. Devices must be switched off.
The organizers hold the right to check for these devices and their usage and disqualify the team.
The time measured by the organizers will be final and will be used for scoring the teams. Time measured by any contestant by any other means is not acceptable for scoring.
In case of any disputes/discrepancies, the organizers’ decision will be final and binding.
The organizers reserve the right to change any or all of the above rules as they deem fit.

Changes in rules, if any, will be highlighted on the website and notified to the registered teams.

Only one team is allowed to be present during the run, other teams will have to stay outside the hall. No team is allowed to take photographs or record their run.

Judging and scoring:

The score will be solely decided on the time taken to cover the entire path. In any other cases, the judge’s decision will be final and binding.

Tiebreaker:

In case of tied times, priority goes to the team with fewer attempts to achieve the objective.

Eligibility:

All students with a valid Student identity card from their respective educational institutes are eligible to participate.

Structure:

It will be conducted on 3rd April, 2024 starting from 10:00 A.M. to 1:00 p.m. (Day 1 of CONVOKE 7.0 ROBOTICS).
The top 3 teams at the end with the highest score will be declared as the winners of the competition.

Certificate policy:

Teams ranking 1st to 3rd receive physical certificates, and all participants get e-certificates.

Registration fees are non-refundable under any circumstances.

title: Blind Coding
organizer: Department of Computer Science Delhi University
description:
Prepare for an electrifying challenge where your coding prowess is pushed beyond limits. In this mind-bending competition, you'll tackle coding problems—but with a twist. Your code remains invisible, hidden from your screen, leaving you to rely solely on logic, memory, and pure problem-solving skills.Can you conquer the chaos, navigate the unseen, and emerge as the ultimate Blind Code Champion?
Guidelines:

Language Allowed C , C++, Python,Java
Team size: Lone wolves
No of problems: 3
Duration of the round : 1 hour

Rules:

Exercise caution! Teams can briefly activate their screens thrice for 30 seconds each, but beware, as a penalty of 5 points will be incurred per activation, closely monitored by our organizers.(Only 1 time activation per question).
Codes will be tested on certain test cases designed by us.
Success and efficiency are key! Priority will be given to code that executes flawlessly with the most optimal solution and highest score.
In the event of errors, elegance prevails! The second preference will go to code with the fewest errors.
In the case of a tiebreaker, timing is everything. The submission time will serve as the final determinant.
Decisions made by the event organizers will be final and binding.

title: H42
description:
Event Description
Do you enjoy coding but fail to realize its significance in the real world? Do you get bored with the mundane problems you get to solve? Do you yearn to do more? Event Rules

This is a team event. Each team comprises 1-3 members. Inter-college teams are also allowed.
